150016270.review:
Classic tactical RPG that holds up pretty well to this day. As someone that doesn't usually have the patience to play any older tactical games, the gameplay in Disgaea feels pretty fast. Building a team feels satisfying due to the many ways of increasing stats and how much unit customization there is (although not nearly as much as in the later NIS games). That's not to say the game is balanced, some classes are objectively inferior to others, and there is one post-game class that is simply better than every other in the game (including the main characters).

The story is better than I expected, it's fun and lighthearted, but has some very good and even emotional points. Part of that may be due to my expectations for it being relatively low, knowing it is a satirical game. I didn't expect actual character development and likeable characters among the humour and tropes.

There is some post-game content and very strong superbosses, but getting to them involves a lot of grinding, and figuring out faster ways to grind and power up your units. If you don't enjoy that, you might not engage with this part of the game. Either way, finishing the story can take about 40 hours, so there's still plenty of content in the main progression.

From the few tactical NIS games I have played, they have a very distinct and pleasant feel to them that I can't really put into words, but for that reason, I do recommend giving them a try.

146351481.review:
Quick:

3/5

Disgaea PC is a pretty decent game.  The characters are funny and love-able, and the story is also.  As far as the story is concerned, it is one of my favorite games.  Most of the dialogue and sub-pots have a tongue-in-cheek type of delivery.  My main problem with the game is the difficulty curve, and the convoluted leveling system and mechanics.

More:

If you've heard anything about Disgaea, you have probably heard that it's 'grindy'.  This is an understatement.  You may stumble upon some forum posts that suggest it's not 'really' grindy, and that you just have to know some 'tricks' to level up fast.  Don't believe them.  If a game requires a cheese strat or some sort of exploitation of the AI or the design to get around the intended grindy way to play... then it is grindy by definition.  This game is grindy... period.  Repeating a single level 100 times to level up easy does not suggest it's not grindy, it proves that it is.  

I put about 55 hours into this game, and about half of that time was spent in the item world playing randomly generated levels repeatedly, and trying to get my characters to a high enough level to beat the story.  The item world is not fun.  Leveling up the way the game intends for you to level up is not fun.  It's mind-numbingly boring and repetitive.  It's a waste of time.  In general, I do not respect games that do not respect my time.  This game is the king of not respecting your time.  

The main problem in this game is the way that your characters level up.  The only way they gain a level is by actually killing enemies.  So... if you have a dedicated healer, and they only heal... they can't level up.  You have to actually use the healer to kill an enemy to level up.  This is stupid.  This is a dumb way to level up characters in an RPG.  You do not get experience for hitting the enemy, or clearing battles... you have to actually deal a killing blow to get experience.

The second problem with this game is the difficulty curve.  You do not naturally level up to keep pace with your enemies.  Every new chapter brick-walls you as soon as you enter it.  The enemies are much stronger than you are, and it seems like the designers actually want you to spend at least twice as long leveling between each chapter than the amount of time that the chapter takes to play.  It's impossible to do it any other way. There are not enough enemies in the main game to level up fast enough to avoid grinding outside of the story line.  

The reason this game is not a 1 out of 5 is because I love the characters and the story.  The music, the artwork, the dialogue, voice acting etc... are great.  I usually have a really fun time playing this game when I'm not grinding to become strong enough to beat the next level.  There are tons of fun mechanics in this game, that other RPGs don't usually have.  The way you level up items is awesome.  Geo Symbols are items that change the terrain of battle so that they give different buffs and de-buffs to enemies and your characters.  It's a very interesting mechanic.

Like I've stated earlier.  I've put 55 hours into this game, and a large portion of it is grinding.  I believe that I am close to the end of the game now... but I have yet again been stopped dead in my tracks by an unreasonable increase in difficulty.  This was the straw that broke the camels back.  I don't feel like grinding anymore to get strong enough to finish the game.  I'm bored with it.  I would love to see how this game ends, but I really don't care enough to keep pushing buttons and killing the same enemies over and over.  If I get back to this game and actually finish it... that's fine.  If I never finish it... that's fine.  It's no longer fun, and I don't really care anymore.

I do plan on playing the sequels some day.  However, if I get the slightest hint that they play the same way as this game, then I have already decided I'm cutting my losses and quitting before I even really get started.  I think this type of game-play is bad.  More game does not necessarily equal a better game.  Disgaea PC needs to do less to be better.

The story itself is rather simple and generic, yet funny and super cheesy in its own way.

139749989.review:
Yes this is a recommend, but only if you don't have a Nintendo Switch. I'll explain why the Switch version is much much better later, but first I'll finish up my recommendation here.
---------------------------------------------------------
Most of the Nippon Ichi SRPG's are probably worth a play if you like the genre. They almost all have several unique gameplay gimmicks, metagame elements, a class unlock system, various grindy optional dungeons or mechanics for powerleveling both characters and items (yes items have levels), post-game content and a ridiculously high level cap. Disgaea 1 codified a lot of these aspects.

None of the Disgaea games have what I call "great" stories, but Disgaea 1 had a very good character driven story focused mostly around the 3 main characters. Laharl and Etna are both bratty demons, and Flonne is a naive angel, leading to some hilarious character interactions as they play off each other. Disgaea 1 actually deserves a lot of credit for creating the setting for the series, as the setting is pretty interesting. Essentially demons, angels, and humans all live in different worlds and each have sort of their own unique culture and quirks. As Disgaea takes place mostly in the netherworld (where demons live), we get exposed to the idea of a race of people who to some degree have inverted morality, with bad behavior being to some degree celebrated. This is a game where you try to pass gameplay changing bills through a senate, and are allowed to simply beat up senators who don't vote for your bill without it being considered a bad thing, and it's entirely in character for the setting.

But enough about that, what about gameplay? Well, you have a base panel where you deploy and can return units, and can send up to 10 out to go fight in turn based combat. It's got the typical mechanics with special attacks, magic, stats that do what they are supposed to, etc. But there's also other unique mechanics like team attacks if your units are adjacent, or being able to lift and throw both allied and enemy units. However there are also some metagame elements here as the game is built to encourage powerleveling units to absurd degrees. For example in the hub, you can create a unit who will be a pupil to another unit. Anytime the pupil levels up, the mentor gets stat boosts. The mentor can also be taught the pupil's spells, which is important if you want to get the most out of Flonne. You can also reincarnate units to reduce their level to 1 while keeping a percentage of their stats and abilities based on how much mana you use to reincarnate them, which makes them easier to keep leveling.

I could go into detail about dozens of more quirky mechanics, like passing bills to increase enemy levels. But the point is this game has way way more depth than it appears at first glance. Ignore my displayed hour count.  That's just for the PC version. I also own this game on PS2, DS, and Switch, and likely have a combined total of over 300 hours on it... And this is probably my least favorite Disgaea game in terms of game mechanics. In many ways it gets better from here. Still, while this is also probably the hardest Disgaea game, and most of the games have nothing to do with the other games, I still think this is the best one to start with even with it's flaws.

---------------------------------------------------------
Now for the caveat I gave at the beginning. The Switch version is almost certainly the best version. It has HD sprites, some gameplay conveniences such as letting healers get exp from healing, and letting you reassign characters commands if the enemy dies prior to them attacking. It also has more overall postgame content. Additionally, this game is just generally the type of game you want to play on a handheld if you can. 

The PC version is indeed the second best version. But it still loses out heavily to the Switch version. 

Additionally this game in any of it's versions has a lot of issues caused by "first installment syndrome". Monsters can not get weapons that boost their int or spell range, making magic monsters almost worthless. Monsters have an abysmally stupid class unlock system where you have to defeat a certain amount of a monsters of a specific type and tier in order to reduce the cost to make them, and there isn't enough to balance monsters in general with humanoid classes. The Dark Assembly feature has and lacks a number of mechanics that make it kind of a chore to use compared to future games. The Item World (random dungeons generated in items to level them up), lacks almost every mechanic associated with it throughout the series, making them often boring grindfests. Weapons are seriously unbalanced, with Swords, Staffs and Guns outperforming everything, while Bows are borderline worthless. Most classes lack special abilities, making some just outright upgrades of others. It's a good game despite all of these problems, but know that the general gameplay for this one is in a lot of ways worse than even just Disgaea 2, let alone everything that comes after.

133338603.review:
This is not a nostalgia review; it is from a first time playthrough.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
[i]Disgaea[/i] is a surprisingly good 20-year old game that holds up. Tactical combat is fast paced and diverse. Individual character abilities are narrow, but made up for by huge team flexibility. [i]Disgaea[/i] doesn’t just lean into the cliché and tropes…it puts on full scuba gear and dives on in.  That said, it is still a 20-year old [i]JRPG,[/i] with several mechanics that would be “grindy” or “timewasters” today. They were easy to ignore, though, so I end up rating  [i]Disgaea[/i] pretty highly.
[hr][/hr]
[i]Disgaea[/i] clearly isn’t perfect. It’s a bit dated…cliché…tropey…with a story that is low-mid grade at best. But it knows exactly what it is and doesn’t pretend to be anything else. By knowing exactly what it wanted to be, it became one of the absolute best dated, cliché, tropey, mid-grade stories I probably ever will play. From the cackling evil overlord with a heart of gold…to the innocent, schoolgirl angel that still believes evil can learn to love…to the robot that literally starts every line by monotonically, and literally, saying BEEP BEEP BLIP BEEP. By the end, you don’t cringe for the clichés or tropes, you cheer. A HUGE part of this is the fantastic voice acting. Despite hamming it up big time, every actor knew exactly how to make each character be taken seriously.

Unlike a lot of JRPGs, [i]Disgaea[/i] is a squad based tactical game. While not nearly on the same level as [i]Final Fantasy Tactics[/i], the tactical combat was enjoyable, and fast paced enough that it doesn’t feel grindy. Each character starts with a few abilities based on their class, and different abilities from their weapon. You only level your character when you kill a baddie, and your abilities/skills/spells only improve when you cast them. If you cast all [b]Ice[/b] spells and no [b]Shield[/b] spells, you will be casting [b]Omgea Ice[/b] by level 40, but your [b]Shield[/b] will be useless. This gets troublesome when your healers, who have no good attacks, stop leveling…sure their healing keeps getting better, but it’s a problem when they only have, like, 5 HP. I don’t want to turn into a guide…so I’ll just say that once you understand the class and character system, there are ways around this. But if you don’t research that stuff before you play, you probably will have a healer with the endurance of a soap bubble.

Since characters only start with skills based on their class and weapon, they don’t have a lot of options. You are expected to bring up to 10 different characters into the battle. Instead of building a small number of superheroes, you need to build a wide range of characters you can call on for any particular battle. Fortunately, this is a [i]JRPG[/i] at heart, so character/skill/gear management is fairly straightforward. You actually get to play the game instead of spending a ton of time managing a large group of characters.

As a very traditional [i]JRPG[/i], it has a number of flaws, like poor pacing (you only get to do 3-5 story missions before the level of the mission is way too high for your characters, and your only options to level are to grind up a few items similar to wandering around looking for random encounters). Excessive minigames that you could literally sink hundreds of hours into. Death in a long dungeon might mean you have redo the whole thing.  And a party with huge level splits, thanks to XP only given when contributing to a kill (I had a level 35 healer with my level 62 main character).

One thing I will give [i]Disgaea[/i] is that it had at least one fun minigame, it let you level up fairly painlessly, and gave you something good for your effort.  Item World.  You can take any piece of gear and go into a tactical combat game with 10 back-to-back levels. Each one you win powers up your gear, along with XP and leveling up skills. Hit that level roadblock on the story? Go level up a few pieces of your favorite gear and get back to it. Way more fun, satisfying, and in-game rewarding than chocobo farming. 

The ”Senate” minigame, on the other hand, made zero sense to me. I spent maybe an hour on it and gave up. It just wasn’t fun. Fortunately, I was able to essentially ignore it, and still fully play and enjoy all the other parts of [i]Disgaea.[/i]

Both the Senate and Item World minigames are deep…way too deep to be rational. But, if for some weird reason you want to play [i]Disgaea[/i] for hundreds of hours, you can do that by playing those two “minigames”.  They are so deep that the story missions become a joke, and you need to ask the Senate to level up the baddies…several times, just to make it interesting again.

Overall, [i]Disgaea[/i] was a really fun game. It has some flaws, but they are largely ignorable.

Long review follows. Ratings at the end, skip to there if you can’t tolerate words.

This is, after trying four versions of this game including this one - in my honest opinion - not the best edition of the game, but if you're looking to play the most "original" version, it'll do well. Check out the mobile version ((yes, I am serious)) or if you have a platform that can play Disgaea 1 Complete, I recommend that over this. Is Disgaea PC bad? Absolutely not. But you should be aware that other options exist.

Disgaea was a series I was somewhat aware of as I grew up. Unfortunately, some rather overzealous fans of the series had kind of put me off wanting to do anything with it. I had never even been aware what kind of game it was until I saw it being played. After that, I decided to pick it up myself - I am a huge fan of Tac-RPG series such as Final Fantasy Tactics and Fire Emblem.

I spent the vast majority of my 40+ hours in Disgaea PC on a single stayover at a friend's house - at the time I was playing Disgaea 1 on Switch. I had put some brief time into Disgaea PC, but it had been many years and I could barely remember there being any differences at all.

I cannot begin to describe the differences, so I won't bother. Instead, I'll just say Disgaea PC "won't hold your hand" and is "hard on purpose". Disgaea 1 Complete on the other hand seems to have a more balanced play style that is more welcoming overall, instead of only to a niche demographic. Skill issues notwithstanding, it is possible to enjoy either version of this game.

Time for me to rake in all the haters. All in all I didn't really feel any of the characters or the plot was very memorable in extreme ((I am one of the few here who will say as much - do note I really just mean the plot/chars were okay, but I didn't especially have many events or people I actually liked)). Look, it's not that I really hated or even disliked the characters - I felt each of them served their plot role pretty well - some maybe a little too well, even. The best way I can describe it is the game seemed overly, massively and especially focused on tropes over actual world-building. You'll get a lot of events and personal relationships happening on-screen, a lot of hilarious hi-jinks and posturing, but very little lore or history about the world within the game. 

Honestly, the troop creation menu does a better job explaining the culture of the Netherworld than the whole rest of the game seemed to - and this is something that really didn't sit well with me, as from what I could tell, the Netherworld itself sounded like a very interesting world to get into from a lore perspective. Not to say that world-building was completely left out - I just feel there wasn’t anywhere near enough.

The thought put into the game's systems when we get to unit creation, however - those are done very, very well. For one, this game has the ability to create and upgrade units that goes above and beyond any tac-RPG I have played. As far as Reincarnating and even switching between unit types and carrying over Spells, the Mentor system to teach a unit Spells and powers from other units, it's absolutely spectacular. Honestly, if that was the entire game, hundreds of missions with zero actual plot and constantly leveling created units, I'd be sold on that alone. I've created many hierarchies and dynasties of units that I became heavily invested in - often to the point of finding the completely overpowered "main characters" to be just in the way of my own enjoyment. 

There is also the Item World, something which the game briefly introduces to you early on and something I heavily recommend NOT skipping over until the end - do what you can as you can do it. It’s a worthwhile investment that does much more for you as you play the game than it would at the very end of all the plot.

There's other unique features to the Disgaea tac-RPG and the series as a whole ((such as the Hospital rewards, Geo Symbols, throwing your units or combining enemy units)) but I won't go over in detail how all these mechanics work - this is a review, not a guide. All I will say is that if you're looking for a game that'll give you countless hours of enjoyment and some unpredictable hilarity, you would be hard pressed to find many that do it as well as Disgaea.

Does this game have unique, differentiated characters who are simple enough to understand yet complex enough to go through their own struggles and have their own motivations? Yes.

But I found myself much more drawn in by the complexity in the units themselves and how they operated and grew over time as I progressed through the game. 

In a time in my life where I basically stopped playing almost every RPG around, Disgaea still managed to impress me, and I’ll likely continue playing it, and the series, for a while after this.




All in all TL;DR Review

Game: 9/10. Fantastically solid. You should play it through at least once.
Plot: 4/10. Expected much, much more from the insane levels of hype.
Characters: 6/10. Not bad, but not especially memorable to me personally.
Music: 9/10. Exactly as zany as it needs to be, while staying expressive.
Combat: 10/10. Always keeps me on my toes, gives me lots of options. 
Relevancy: 9/10. Disgaea manages to stick in my games even almost 8 years later.

Value for your price - Well worth the purchase.
Are other options besides this version available? Yes.
But if you're looking for a game on PC, I do recommend you play through Disgaea.

128478987.review:
[h1]Easy to recommend as an introduction to Tactical RPGs (TRPGs). Expansive post-game, forgiving difficulty, and an endearing story.[/h1]

This series' reputation of being a grindfest is overblown by people who avoid the Item World. There's a clear point of diminishing returns you'll hit if you're repeating story stages for experience points, and many people don't take the hint to move on.

Don't let my playtime fool you; that's thanks to two "from scratch" save files, and collecting/maxing out every ultimate weapon for fun. If your only goal's completing all of the alternative endings, getting the best ultimate weapon [spoiler](Yoshitsuna)[/spoiler], and then killing [spoiler]Baal/Zetta[/spoiler], you're probably in for a good fifty hours altogether.

[h1]Do yourself a favor and play using a speedhack. 3x speed is comfortable for doing Item World runs if your CPU has the overhead for it.[/h1]

If Disgaea suffers from one thing, it's that you're implicitly pressured to make one uber-powerful character. This throws the "T" out of "TRPG", as instead of your units each being like keys; useful in specific circumstances but useless in others; you have one 80ft skeleton key in the form of a battering ram. As if this wasn't busted enough, you can reach even more ludicrous heights, literally and figuratively, by exploiting its [b]"lift and throw"[/b] mechanics.

[h1]Cheese! 🧀[/h1]

Friendly units in this game can lift hostile units, as well as each other. This, when coupled with the ability to "undo" the movement action of a unit, allows them to politely hold doors open for each other (if the unit hasn't attacked/cast a spell/etc. during their turn). Chokepoint with a big bad got you down? Exit gate three squares away, but you can't reach it?

No problem. Just send Stinky Wizzleteats, your Level 1 Incompetent Rogue, to lift that level 5000 chimera, move your 'battering ram' unit [i]behind[/i] your enemy's carefully crafted line, and then cancel the lift.

This sends Stinky back to his starting position (even despawning him for later retrieval if his starting position was the Dimensional Gate), and your competent unit that's already passed through gets to keep his new position.

If this isn't playing dirty enough for you, you can also lift units lifting units. In the item world, this means you can typically clear each floor in a single round by creating stacks of six friendly units all throwing each other. Still not grimy enough? Take on a superboss, sucker punch it with your strongest unit, and then lift said strongest unit with another friendly one.

The superboss will Dr. Manhattan your sacrificial friendly, but no hostile NPCs will target the now-dropped friendly, and the round will end. [b][i]You can do this up to nine times per stage.[/i][/b]

[i][b]I love this game.[/b][/i]


[h1]Tips for Being Overlord:[/h1]


[olist][*][b]Focus Development on Custom Characters[/b]

You won't always have access to Story characters. While they do retain their stats, levels, and equipment, on subsequent playthroughs you [b][i]will[/i][/b] need to re-acquire many of them.

[*][b]Weapon Stats and Mastery v.s. Character Level[/b]

Don't worry about cumulative character level through reincarnations as much as equipment level and weapon mastery. You'll see better returns this way. A total level of 9,000 is perfectly adequate to complete all the game's content.

[*][b]Maxing Equipment Stat Growth[/b]

When you have a weapon you want to maximize the potential of, enter its Item World and subdue its specialists immediately upon entering before using a 'Gency's Exit' to escape. If you don't find a specialist right away, reload a save.

Once you've subdued all specialists, move in [b][i]stat-boosting specialists, all complementing the attributes you care most about.[/i][/b] With this done, re-enter the Item World, and skip to the exit of nine of every ten levels. Every tenth level you'll encounter an 'Item General'. Kill [b][i]every unit on these floors.[/i][/b]

Every thirtieth, sixtieth, and ninetieth floor of items strong enough to have that many will award you with an additional slot for a specialist. After completing these stages, use a 'Gency's Exit' and fill the item to capacity. Then, re-enter.

This influences the stat growth of items enough to make a big difference over time.

[*][b]Maxing Weapon Potential[/b]

When you have a new custom unit you've created in the Dark Assembly, make them a Majin. Then, train them up with the weapon you plan to have them using as their final class using a level 300 Armsmaster in their equipment. This will boost the speed they improve their Weapon Mastery with that weapon type immensely, to a maximum value of 255.

[b]Weapon Mastery increases the stats of a weapon, but no other piece of a unit's equipment, by 5% per level. [u]By level 255, this increases to 1275%.[/u][/b]

[*][b]Bribing the Dark Assembly on a Budget[/b]

Once you've gotten the alternative ending for [spoiler]killing the Dark Assembly 100 times in a playthrough to force bills to pass[/spoiler], call the Assembly to raise the military budget and bribe senators with the cheapest trash you can buy. Only bother giving an item to a senator who "Must Have!", "Strongly Interested", or "Interesting". In that order.

Once a Senator's disposition has reached [b]'Love ♥'[/b], don't give them anything else. They're maxed out.

[*][b]Underworld Civics Class: How to Actually Pass a Bill[/b]

Bills proposed to the Dark Assembly will only pass if the sum of the character levels of those in favor is greater than those against by a margin equalling the Mana cost needed to propose the bill in the first place.

Realistically, this means you'll likely be killing the Dark Assembly to unlock a handful of levels most playthroughs.

[*][b]Don't Reincarnate Just to Learn the Skills of Another Class[/b]

Mentors can learn "generic" humanoid abilities from their Pupils if they stand on a tile bordering them. Once the ability has been used enough times to reach at least "Level 1", they can then use said ability without their Pupil present.

[*][b]Mentor/Pupil Stat Gain and Matching Rarity Bonuses[/b]

A Mentor's Pupil with the highest value for a given stat is referenced for a 10% bonus to their Mentor.

A separate bonus altogether, matching the rarity value across all four equipment slots on a single character gives more significant returns. This said, it's worth chasing when reloading Item World Level 100 and [spoiler]Baal once per playthrough for a Super Robo Suit[/spoiler].

If you have two items with the same Rarity value, you gain a 10% bonus to all stats conferred by said items. You get 20% for 3 items, and 30% when all four equipment slots match.

Why I said "wait for endgame" comes down to number ranges. A Legendary-rarity item only has ten possible rarity values, so in addition to having the most room for stat growth thanks to a higher max item level, you also have a far greater chance of stealing a complement to your existing gear.

[*][b]Only Level Weapons and [spoiler]Super Robo Suits[/spoiler][/b]

No matter how good the Armor, until [spoiler]Super Robo Suits[/spoiler], Accelerators and their Movement/Jump bonuses are some of the best equipment in the game for the number of options better positioning gives you.

[*][b]The Only Armor Worth Equipping is Accelerators and Footwear Until Endgame[/b]

Movement and Jump bonuses have a much greater return on investment, and are far more versatile (especially for support units).

Orbs are sometimes worth it for increased SP capacity early-game.[/olist]

Disclaimer: I'm biased towards Disgaea: Hour of Darkness as it was my first Disgaea game upon it's release. Take anything I say with a grain of salt. This port has issues which, if you look, you can find copious documentation online.

General thoughts: 
I feel like Disgaea has aged well. The gameplay loop is comprised of three major parts - story chapters and stages, the item world, and post-game bosses. You can level your characters, their skills, their weapon mastery (which increases stat gain from the weapon as well as unlocks other bonuses like new weapon skills (or range and damage for staves), and even the items they have equipped by hopping into the Item World.

Story:
The plot is very solid. With no spoilers for those who haven't played the game in it's 20 years of being out, it's a not-so-by-the-books Coming of Age story about a young demon named Laharl as he attempts to prove himself as the new Overlord of the Netherworld. The pacing is pretty quick. Each chapter is divided into about 4-5 stages that develops that section of story almost in a "Saturday Morning Cartoon" way. There's many references to older anime and shows. (Kurtis, a character introduced late into the story, is essentially a giant reference to Cyborg 009). The things in the game can be pretty silly, and writing doesn't hesitate to poke fun of itself, it's characters, or the world they're in.

The gameplay:
At it's core the gameplay is very easy for you to get "lost" in. There's so many numbers you can increase (that you don't have to) that you can essentially pick something and grind. There's a few obvious levels intended to make leveling easy, and others that you can easily level things such as weapon mastery in, so you should never be stuck. The item world is the most aged part of the series, however, with some floors in the randomly generated dungeon spawning a gate you can't reach, or enemies that are on an island you can't get to. Always take a "Mr. Gency's Exit" with you just you case. This problem has been fixed, from what I can tell, in the Disgaea 1 Complete port.

All of this being said...

If you have the option between this version or Disgaea 1 Complete on Switch/PS4 I'd recommend you get Disgaea 1 Complete. It increased the "Statistician" innocent cap from 300, to 900, giving you six times more experience gain. It fixed the item world randomization, and it fixed a few known crash issues. The only reason I'm playing this over the other version is for achievements and because I prefer the old sprites. D1C lazily reused D5 sprites of completely different classes instead of drawing new sprites for old monsters that haven't been seen in newer games.

From someone who barely touched SRPGs (being the only ones Pokemon Conquest and Devil Survivor series), the game hits hard due to how many possible strats can be used just on one map. At first sight, the mechanics and gameplay seemed complex, as if it was one of those old-school RPGs where you have to take notes every time you want to compare equipment, stats, optimize classes, and so on. [b]However,[/b] upon playing more and reading guides -and I really mean LOTS of guides-, the flow of the game became more stable.

Starting with the plot, it features a simple yet attracting characters and dialogues. I only got up to chapter 10 at the time I'm writing this review, but so far I'm enjoying everything. Each of the main cast characters are unique, and most of the time the dialogues turns into comedy/slapstick situations, which I absolutely love. While this is a big positive point for me, what really hooked me into it was the next part: the gameplay.

The game rewards you for being patient. The game rewards you for leveling classes, even if they seem useless, and killing monsters -by reducing their mana cost at the Dark Assembly, place where you can create new characters. There are 2 main 'battle', if you can call it like that, scenes: gates, where you can either do main story or another unlockable, and the maps and enemies are pretty much the same, and Item World, a place where the maps and enemies changes constantly, but where you can upgrade your weapons/gear/items. Why did I said I liked the gameplay? Well, the Item World is just addicting. While you upgrade stuff, you also get more items in the way, level up your characters and even gather specialists, which basically are another upgrade to equipment -but that can be moved. It must be warned that Item World takes way too much time, and the grind scene in this game is real. However, the rewards are pretty satisfying, and you can also beat the main story without doing much grind, so it's pretty much balanced.

The only negative points I see with this game, along with the PC port:
- Healers/Supports are useless, as they won't get EXP for healing (and, because of that, they can't upgrade staff mastery nor level up). Thank to one game mechanic, you can teach them spells such as fire, wind or ice, so they can deal some damage. However, as for someone who has 100% new, it took me a lot of time to see that.
- Any I/O device being manipulated with the game open can cause it to crash. Lost Item World progress twice due to my controller being disconnected -thank you for nothing, Steam Big Picture.
- There are some other bugs that may cause the game to crash, but haven't encountered any other so far. However, this, along with the fact that you can't save inside IW, makes it risky to play at times. 
- Dark Assembly. Not that I find it unfair, since there is probably a reason as to why some bills are mostly rejected. However, there's no in-game information about it. Like this, some other mechanics in the game are hidden unless you discover it or read it on a guide. The fact that I'm using DA as an example is mostly because there are no explainations as for bribings before voting, which is one of the most important aspects imo. 
- As I've mentioned above, almost everything is either you discover it or read it somewhere. As such, it might be difficult to properly enjoy the game itself.

Bought for 3.99€ during Steam sale, worth the price but I'd suggest getting the handheld versions (PSP, DS or Switch) if you can't stand sitting in front of a screen to grind for lots of hours. It's also worth mentioning that there are different versions for this game, being them:
[list]
[*] Original (PS2)
[*] PSP (some minor updates)
[*] DS (QoL improvements, new unlockable characters)
[*] PC (somewhat PSP and a little DS, but without the QoL improvements)
[*] HD remake (Switch-PS4, some more QoL improvements)
[/list]
For a 'classic' experience, PC (aka this one) seems the best so far. I'd recommend the HD remake elsewhere, and mostly if you have 0 knowledge about Disgaea at all. Keep in mind, though, that even with QoL improvements, the grind is still present. 

[b]So TL;DR:[/b] if you love to get the very best team, like no one ever was, then this is the perfect game. The grind is kinda entertaining and rewarding, + funny story dialogues and iconic trio main cast.

I have to play it on my Steam Deck though (Using the in-game windowed mode to prevent stretching), because fullscreen on my main Windows PC is actually just borderless fullscreen that stretches the game window, and there' an endless D-Pad moving up issue, no matter what I do (Yes, I've disabled unused controller devices too). Hardcoding resolution options is going to cause problems no matter what.

The port also is stuck at 720p internally (So the game on a large display has problems, and with displays that don't evenly divide by the resolution, it will be overly blurry thanks in no part to the lack of integer scaling), and there's very noticeable flickering/strobing (Which may pose as an accessibility problem for some) with the in-game SSAO implementation. I'd suggest disabling it. Likewise, use a FreeSync monitor to play (or just play on a Steam Deck), because the game is going to have stuttering/frametime problems otherwise, since there's a framerate cap that is not user exposable. You will want to use the PrettyPrinny mod to play the game, but using the lite version in conjunction with recent versions of Special K (For the windowed mode latency optimizations). As far as I'm concerned, this release of the game also lacks the content from the mobile version (Which is usually cheaper than this version without discounts), or the Nintendo Switch releases. There is a mod to add some of the content from the PSP version, but it also seemingly breaks compatibility with PrettyPrinny.

Can I recommend this game based off the time I've played? Probably, need more time to think about it, may change the yes/no recommendation once I play more. Probably with some massive asterisks especially in the UX department, because the PC port definitely has some problems that never got addressed officially, and spending hours in a debugger trying to get the game work is something that I personally would rather not do if possible.

This game is very unique. I have never seen a game with similar gameplay like this before. However, since it's a unique game, it can be very different. In some mostly good ways, but a few bad ways, as well.

[u]The good stuff:[/u] I love the amazing style of this game. Its artwork, its gameplay, its music, and especially its humor. I haven't laughed at any other game more than this one. From its sexual comments to its item descriptions, I find a lot of creative writing put into this game. The way that items work in this game is unique, too. You can tailor any item VERY in-depth. You can upgrade its stats, such as the statistician class which will give you experience, you can upgrade its strength, health, etc. You can hire a huge number of classes. Once you defeat an enemy in the game, you can "tame" it by spending mana on it, letting it become your sidekick. You can level it up from there.

[u]The bad stuff:[/u] This game is grindy as fuck. 85% of the hours that I put into this game is grind. The game isn't very "beginner-friendly" if you're starting out the Disgaea series with this game first. That's what I read online, at least. The story doesn't progress your levels. You have to put in lots of effort in order to get better, which results in you using guides in order to find the best strategies to level you up. However, with some cheese and a decent strategy, I beat it in about 3-4 attempts.

[u]Overall:[/u] I believe that the pros outweigh the cons slightly. I found plenty of joy in this game, but towards the end, it felt more like a chore. I wanted to finish the game so that I could move onto something else, but the game gets very repetitive at times. When I continue to the other Disgaea games, I'm hoping that they will be easier than this one.

Play with controller, or if you can't, reconfigure the buttons for confirm/cancel/menu (Z/X/C)
as while Enter and Esc are universal context buttons, they are extremely sensitive for some reason.

If the game stops working i.e. it crashes on startup,
go to 86x/ There should be a new folder called OpenAL.
Install the .exe in there and that will fix it.
The game will still probably crash every other instance
you launch, but this is the only workable solution I know of.

Play with original menu graphics.
Not only does it look better, but new graphics are cut off/choppy and block some menu elements.

Finally, you can skip animations by setting enemy effect/friendly effect to off.
Incredible fix saving hundreds of hours.

How to play:

Step 1. Play the game normally by getting Laharl to a decent level by soloing the game with him (30-40) then have him specifically make a red mage and get that mage to level 12.
Step 2. Capture a high level monster by stacking enemies onto each other and maxing Laharl's attack with Braveheart then having him go back into the base panel, then throw the enemy onto the panel. This is still random so it may fail, don't give up. (Only monster enemies, humanoids always break panel guaranteed)
Step 3. Keep doing this by stacking other enemies ontop of each other to boost their level, capture them, keep stepping up the ladder and progressively capturing higher level monsters.
Step 4. Use the Dark Assembly to make the enemies in the maps stronger = make stronger monsters.
Repeat Step 3.

This is only the first step. As you progress there will be more efficient methods. 
Your new life grinding in the grinder's paradise begins...

108456864.review:
This is the best version of Disgaea 1 before it was remade into the "Complete" version available on Switch, PS4, and mobile (and of those, mobile is the best for the Complete version). I somewhat enjoyed the Strategy/Tactical RPG genre before playing this game (played the Final Fantasy Tactics series, tried playing Ogre Battle, but just couldn't get into this one), but the combination of humor and over the top numbers/gameplay really hooked something into me and I became a fan  of the series. 

I don't believe the graphics for this version of the game have changed at all since the PS2/PSP remake days, and that can certainly throw some people off. I try not to let such things both me, but it does seem extremely dated and a bit ugly when compared to the updated HD character sprites in later games (especially 4 and 5). 

The gameplay mechanics are Disgaea at it's core. Leveling characters up to 9999, then transmigrating them to level 1 with boosted stats, only to do it all over again, like 10+ more times is a series staple, and it started here. This version includes the updates from PSP, which includes a better level grinding spot for end game than the original PS2 version. Item World it at its very basic form, including creating levels where it may be impossible to get to enemies/geo crystals. I personally have never encountered an random item world level that didn't have the next level portal within reach of the starting portal space, but I could just be lucky. The game DOES warn you about this, though.

This version of the game does, unfortunately, lack quite a few QoL features that were introduced in other, later games. You can speed up battle animations, and skip them entirely, but can't speed up characters movement. Once you've moved a character (but haven't confirmed an action for them), you can't simply reposition then if you accidentally moved them to the wrong spot. If you cancel their move, it sends them all the way back to their original location, including back into the base panel, where you would have to completely re-select them and then move them again. This, combined with the slow character movement, can really slow down grinding/item world exploration. The views you are able to change to in battle are more limited, and there's really not a top-down view option (at least that I've found), which can make positioning and even finding characters/items (especially in item world) tricky. You can see which bonus bosses you've beaten, but can't see a list of which endings you've gotten. I would absolutely love if some of these QoL improvements were implemented in a patch, but I believe that will never happen at this point.  NIS, at least give us Disgaea 1 Complete, even if it is the crappy Switch/PS4 version, dood!

So, if you want to experience the original, non Complete remake version of Disgaea 1, this is the game for you. If you can deal with the issues mentioned (because you absolutely love the series, like me, and are willing to deal with the flaws in this version, or have just never played a Disgaea game, and are looking to get into it from where it started), then this game is for you. I do love this game (and the series in general), but wish there were some QoL updates from later games.

[h1]Context[/h1]
Before I came to know of this game, I was an avid fan of the Fire Emblem Series. One day, I had been browsing on steam and saw the Disgaea Dood Bundle on sale for an astounding price (around $20?). I saw that this game had the [i]Strategy RPG[/i] tag on it, but saw no review comparing this game to Fire Emblem. I decided to try the game out considering these factors.
At the moment, I have completed the Main Story of the game, but there are more features to it. As I read in a guide, the main story is about 5% of the game (grinding and achievements constitute the 95%).
Oh, and by the way, the maximum level threshold is Level [spoiler]9999[/spoiler]. My party, at the time of completing my main story, averaged around Level [spoiler]52[/spoiler]. The enemies in the final level averaged around Level [spoiler]80[/spoiler].

[h1]Comparison to Fire Emblem[/h1]
This game is radically different than Fire Emblem, with the introduction of new mechanics such as:
[spoiler]
[olist]
[*] Lifting and Throwing Allies
[*] Moving after attacking (if you attacked and didn't move in that same turn)
[*] Area of Effect Special Skills. 
[*] Geo Crystals (Provides bonuses for certain colored squares)
[*] Replaying previous levels for Grinding
[*] Team Attacks and Chain Attacks (different from Linked Attacks)
[*] Upgrading items by going through the "Item Dungeon"
[*] Senators (my least favorite mechanic) and bribing them
[*] Capturing Enemies (throwing them into the base plate - capture them by successfully defending against the enemy.)
[*] And more!
[/olist]
[/spoiler] 
(Don't worry, the spoilers show Disgaea's game mechanics over Fire Emblem.)

In Fire Emblem, you may think, [i]"How can I defeat this enemy without endangering one of my units?"[/i]
In Disgaea, you may think, [i]"If this [spoiler]Geo Crystal[/spoiler] is here, then this will cause a chain reaction with this one and that one, etc."[/i]

What really sets them both apart is the [b][u]Grind[/u][/b]. In Fire Emblem, you may reach the point where Experience is scarce, and you're at the point where you're "benching" certain units (I believe this means not including them in your battle party) in order to feed Experience to stronger units. In Disgaea, you grind all your units to your heart's content. For me, I got very tired of replaying levels over and over for the Grind. However, it exists for people who live for that experience.

Due to this, strategy is necessary if you don't grind. The only times I seriously considered my strategy was in the first chapter and the final chapter. 

[h1]Level Design[/h1]
Most levels are designed well and allow for nice gameplay. However, there are a few "vexing" levels in some chapters that I genuinely found annoying and frustrating. 
Most of these vexing levels make it so enemies are impossible to kill without destroying the [spoiler]Geo Crystal[/spoiler] that provides the boost. By the way, these [spoiler]Geo Crystals[/spoiler] are at the opposite end of the map. It'll take you around 8 turns to get there - meanwhile you will be attacked by enemies with long-range capabilities.
Otherwise, most maps are well suited for the chapter and allow for great gameplay or tactical advantage.

[h1]Story (Be careful about your mouse pointer!)[/h1]
I really enjoyed the story as I played through the game. The story is generated in a fantasy world, starring the [spoiler]Netherworld[/spoiler], [spoiler]Celestia[/spoiler], and oddly enough, [spoiler]Earth[/spoiler]. The game begins with a [spoiler]young prince (Laharl) seeking to become Overlord after learning about his father's death[/spoiler]. Early on, [spoiler]Laharl is evil, and attempts to become Overload through Physical force[/spoiler]. With the introduction of [spoiler]the other main character, Flonne, Laharl gradually learns to "love". In the game's context, "love" can be likened to "Compassion"[/spoiler]. 
The conflict is [spoiler]the stereotype that Demons are Evil and are incapable of showing "love". Flonne, in her adventure to the netherworld, seeks to prove the stereotype wrong, and finds out that Demons (most notably, Laharl) [i]are[/i] capable of showing "love".[/spoiler]

Because the Good Ending is believed to be Canon, I strongly suggest getting this ending. On my play-through, I had gotten the Normal Ending, which I found to be the saddest one. 
To achieve the Good Ending (a how-to; contains no story spoilers): [spoiler]Finish the game without killing any ally. Be careful, especially with special skills. The Normal Ending is achieved with 1 Ally Kill or more.[/spoiler]

In short, I enjoyed the story of the game. I enjoyed the main character's character development, and all the characters that helped him develop.
Who's my favorite character, you ask? My favorite character in the entire game is [spoiler]Gordon, the Defender of Earth[/spoiler]. Why? Although he may be your stereotype comic book hero, his unwavering ego, pride, and sense of justice is what sets him apart. He is absolutely hilarious when other characters damage his ego. He may have been a comic relief character, but his introduction certainly caught my attention, and subsequent chapters have been more enjoyable with his presence.


[h1]Strengths[/h1]
[list]
[*] Character creation - Make as many party members as needed.
[*] Lifting & Throwing - Allows for easier mobility and new strategies. 
[*] Basic Stats System - RPG fans will understand what each stat does quickly.
[*] Strong Story - Game revolves around the character development of the main character.
[*] Fantasy World - Game's setting introduces stereotypes and beliefs we hold in our culture.
[*] Multiple Endings - Several endings. The "Good" Ending is considered Canon.
[*] Character Development - Noticeable change in main character's personality throughout the story. 
[*] Long Game - Main Story can take around 50 hours to complete, based on how much you are grinding.
[/list]

[h1]Weaknesses[/h1]
[list]
[*] "Love" [spoiler]isn't Love - hoped for courting with Laharl and Flonne due to strong emphasis on "love". Although the game suggests mutual feelings, it never happened[/spoiler].
[*] Grinding -  [u]Excessive[/u] grinding is necessary in post-game, according to guides. 
[*] Status Effect Information - The game doesn't tell you what each Status Effect does.
[*] Skill Base - The game doesn't tell you whether a character's skill uses your INT, ATK, or HIT stat.
[*] Vexing Levels - Some levels will be straight up frustrating.
[*] Senators. 
[*] No auto-saving - save manually.
[/list]

Thank you for reading my review! (This is my first review!)

When compared to modern RPGs, the original Disgaea isn't going to hold up very well. A lot of the quality of life changes from later games in the series aren't there, making it feel like a bit of a grind. I think it probably would have benefited from including a fast-forward feature, which I think is critical to making old games feel a little more bearable.

And don't get me wrong... there are old games out there that I would gladly suffer through their slow pace. However, Disgaea doesn't have a plot that's going to stick with you. The anti-hero gimmick starts out interesting, but the plot just doesn't bring anything to keep you going. Each chapter really only has a few plot points, and although there's not a ton of levels per chapter, you'll likely need to either replay levels or work your way through the item world in order to be strong enough to keep progressing. The grind is not as bad as I expected given the game's reputation, but still worse than I would prefer.

There are people out there that love this game, and I completely understand why. However, I would not recommend it to the majority of people. If you find the concept interesting, I'd start on a later entry in the series (the plots are not interlinked), and then decide from there if you like the systems enough to muscle through the earlier implementations.

99405867.review:
A few things before I start with the review, don't pay attention to the people that give it a bad review saying stuff like "why NIS America doesn't port Disgaea 1 complete/Disgaea D2?" Just because there's a superior version of this game doesn't mean that this is a bad game.

2 things more, [b] there's no auto-save, save every time you finish a level [/b], and if you play the game use a spoiler free guide for the characters (there are a few here on steam)

Disgaea is a turn-based strategy JRPG that will require you to pay a lot of attention to what options you have, what option the enemy has and what's the most optimal way of executing them (this is at least in the first 2 Disgaea games, in the more recent games it's not as hard because you have more options at your disposal)
Now, Disgaea 1 is not a game for everyone, and I say this because of the mechanics that it has. Some can feel incredibly outdated like, for example, healers not getting xp from healing allies; and some feel like there's something missing, like throwing allies (you can only do it in a straight line).

-Gameplay
Once you enter a level, you can deploy up to 10 units. Each unit has a set of attributes: abilities, elemental resistances, strong weapons and aptitude. Once you start the level you can first move your units in a square by square map, each unit moves a different amount of squares. When you finish your turn the enemy moves.
Once you finish a level you will have to heal your units, for that there's a healing spot in your base, and if a unit dies you will have to revive it. Every single heal and revive costs money, so managing your units is essential.

}Abilites: special attacks. each unit has their own special abilites, some of them repeat between units and some are unique and cant be learned by other characters. Here comes a mechanic that is called "Mentor/Pupil". Lets say you create a character with Laharl (protagonist), the character that you create becomes your pupil, and if its close to Laharl, Laharl can use that characters abilities.
}Elemental resistances: as it sounds, there's 3 elements, ice wind and fire
}Strong weapons: there's 6 weapons and 1 for monster units, each non-monster unit can use one of those 6 weapons and each unit has a strong weapon that they can use.
}Aptitude: how much a character benefits from certain stats, like HP for example.

-Story
Disgaea's story is quite good, it has both emotional and hilarious moments, and the game knows how to move between them. Most of the events/conversations the characters have are on the funny side, and because of this, when there's an emotional moment it can hit you hard sometimes. 
Once you finish the story you can play "Etna Mode" where you play as Etna, a character from the main cast, in an alternative story. To unlock it you will have to input a code (I haven't played it so I don't have too much to say)

>Pros
-Good story
-Alternative endings 
-Interesting and hilarious characters
-Rewarding gameplay
-Additional mode (Etna mode) that counts as an alternative story and can be as long as the main story

>Cons
-Healers don't get xp from healing
-Some mechanics can feel outdated
-There's no auto-save

>Middle point (some people like some people dislike)
-You might have to grind sometimes
-When you create a character it starts at lvl 1
-You can complete the game with only one character
-Requirements for the endings can be a bit demanding

99364182.review:
Tons of fun, and if it's on sale you really don't have reason to not pick it up. Disgaea is an RPG game that's not like the other RPGs, it's quirky. Turn based strategic tile combat is the core of the games gameplay, but I would describe the game as more of a turn based puzzle game rather than just an RPG. Every encounter is unique and challenging in it's own way, even the maps you are playing on are a big puzzle most the time, and your path to victory is always going to be a little different. 

The writing is witty and funny, the characters are goofy and lovable, the art is stylish and cute, and the soundtrack just doesn't get old. I've put so much time in and still haven't finished, but honestly I've enjoyed every second even the grinding, though I don't feel it's grinding as most people would know it. 

As mentioned above yes there is grinding in this game, but the game has a very clever way of making it challenging and engaging instead of just mashing A to win fights until your team is real strong. The grinding in this game mostly comes in the form of weapon/gear upgrades. Where in you go into the weapon you want to upgrade and fight through randomly generated dungeons, every floor cleared is a level for your weapon, and each floor provides unique challenges to overcome. I've found endless fun in challenging weapon dungeons that are above my level, and managing to crawl past the finish line. The best part is while you are working your way though the dungeons you get tons of levels for your characters AND more gear that will often be better than the gear you are currently trying to level. It's an ultimate roguelite experience in a game that came out before roguelites were super common (Maybe even before they were a thing, don't fact check me). I honestly could play the weapon upgrading portion of this game without ever touching the main story and still have an amazing time. 

My only complaint about the game is that it is an older game, so yeah the graphics are a little blurry being blown up to this higher resolution, but that hasn't stopped me from playing it like crazy, and you can always play in a smaller window if it's getting on your nerves.

All in all, amaizing game, but not for PC. Buy this only if you can't get it on any other platform (preferably PSP or Switch)

93120368.review:
Note: If you're able to, get "Disgaea 1 Complete" on the PS4 or Nintendo Switch instead. Since that one has remastered sprites & additional features which will make your experience much more enjoyable, also includes additional characters. 

For as long as I can remember, I've always had a fascination with numbers going up. Seeing small numbers turn to big numbers is something I absolutely love in video games, and Disgaea is the perfect game for this. They go overkill with numbers. Personally I never write reviews, but I have to for an amazing game like this. I've gotten every single achievement for this game so I believe I have a good idea of everything this game contains.

TLDR: Disgaea has big numbers

[h1] What is Disgaea? [/h1]

Disgaea is a turn-based JRPG/SRPG depending on how you define it, it also has visual novel elements for telling it's story. The narrative segments take place before starting a level & after. 

This game has a unique cast that I found easy to get attached to, each having their own faults and reasons for what they do. If you have an easy time getting attached to characters, you'll most definitely find a cast member in this game you can get attached to (I myself, find it very hard to get attached to cast members, and I ended up getting emotionally attached to around half the cast in this game.). 

Alongside the cast, Disgaea 1 has some of the most memorable soundtracks I've listened to. Disgaea 1 does it's job very well with attaching personal meanings to these soundtracks, when you listen to some specific soundtracks you'll very well be reminded of specific characters or emotional moments in this game.

TLDR: Turn based SRPG/JRPG with visual novel elements, memorable cast & soundtracks.

[h1]What makes Disgaea so special?[/h1]

Disgaea 1 has a level cap of 9,999, which is usually unheard off in video games. I've played games where the level cap is 70-100 then after that is a different type of levelling which has a large cap, but never has any impact on the character's stats. With Disgaea, each level up past 100 will still give you additional stats, there are actually post game bosses that are built to give you a tough time against lvl 9,999 characters. But with other games, I didn't really have any incentive to grind levels since at lvl 70-100 I can overpower everything. In this game, your stats can reach into the millions if you put in the effort. 

This is what makes Disgaea so special to me, no other game has gone as crazy as Disgaea has with levelling and stat caps. Some Disgaea games have increased the stat caps:

Disgaea 1: 20,000,000 max for each stat
Disgaea 2: 40,000,000 max for each stat
Disgaea 4: 99,999,999 max for each stat 

Disgaea 6 is going 10,000 steps further and increasing the level cap to 99,999,999 (99 million), while the stat cap is currently unknown to me. It has been confirmed you can deal over 10,000,000,000,000,000 (10 quintillion) damage!

TLDR: Disgaea is special because of it's lvl 9,999 cap and 20,000,000 stat cap. Increased to 99,999,999 stat cap in further entires, alongside the lvl cap being increased to 99,999,999 in the upcoming Disgaea 6.

[h1]How does the gameplay function in this game?[/h1]

The game itself as previously mentioned is turn based, you get to control up to 10 units on each level (You can make more units then this, but this is the maximum amount of units you're allowed to dispatch). Unit's are usually split up into 2 categories: 

* Story characters
* Generic characters

You're only allowed 1 of each story character, as you've probably guessed. These characters are characters which have story significance, whether it be the main story or small optional side-stories. Sometimes story characters are instantly provided to you in other Disgaea games if you play the Complete variations of them since they're DLC. Same rules apply that you are only allowed 1 of these characters.  

With generic characters, you're allowed to create multiple of them. Each generic unit has their own class, most of these units have a specific purpose for being created (Example: You create a healer for the purpose of healing.). A couple of classes for example are: Healer, Mage, Warrior, Thief, Archer. These are self-explanatory for why you'd want to incorporate these classes into your team.... or don't, I managed to grind my levels up to 200-300 with Laharl (Main character) and blasted every unit that came at me through the story. 

Another important thing in this game is equipment, you get 1 slot for weapons & 3 slots for accessories. You have the option to level these up in what I'd class as a mode called the item world, which to put it brief is a mode in which you go through randomly generated floors. Each time you clear a floor you add an additional level to your item, which in turns increases its overall stats. 

There are features in this game that are based around levelling up, such as the reincarnation/transmigration system which puts you at lvl 1 but gives you an increase in stats. This is something you will most definitely have to do if you want to defeat the most powerful bosses in the game, you will have motive to always level up as you will always have that ultimate challenge boss to kill. 

Last thing I'll mention is something unique to this game called "geo puzzles", there are multiple color panels on the floor. When a geo block is placed on a specific coloured panel, all the panels on top of that geo block that has the same colour will have a unique effect applied to them. When a unit stands on these panels, that effect will be applied to them until they step off the panel. 

It's stated what the geo block effect is while hovering over it (Some effect examples are: invincibility, warp, 3x enemy boost, 20% ally damage, 20% damage etc.). If you play your cards right with this mechanic, you can wipe out enemies that are way more powerful then you. You get a random combination of geo block & panels all the time in the item world.

There's plenty more to discover in Disgaea, I believe this has given you a rough enough idea of what the game entails. I encourage you to play this game yourself and learn the extent of how much you can break this game, 1 level at a time :b 

TLDR: Disgaea is a turn based game, there are plenty of units for you to create (Each with their own advantage and disadvantage), equipment is important in this game and can be levelled up, there's a mechanic in this game based around reaching high lvls then resetting at lvl 1 for an overall increase in your stats. There is an ultimate boss in this game that will require you to reach very high stats. This games unique mechanic, geo blocks can provide advantages/disadvantages to you or the enemy team.

If there's any questions you have regarding Disgaea 1, feel free to add me & DM me. I know this is a lot of information but should be enough to help you decide if this game is for you or not.

88307215.review:
[h1]TL;DR[/h1] 
It spawned an entire franchise and holds up pretty well, but it certainly lacks the modern quality of life changes that have been established over time. Still a good tactical JRPG with a lot of charme.

[h1]What Is This “Thing”?[/h1] 
I really like to play RPGs as they are relaxing, can tell great stories and have distinctive atmospheres that are not easily replicated. Yet Disgaea is a different breed of RPG that feels a lot more like it could be released nowadays.
Disgaea is like a badly written fanfic in terms of themes: demons, angels, and superheroes are all existing and somewhat interacting with each other while still being bound by their respective tropes and some twists. This is unconventional by any means and extremely strange to see, even considering that modern anime and light novels really try to capture the same thing. Disgaea goes further though and has a “heart” behind it all. Normally this set pieces are doomed to fail, despite that I found the interactions entertaining and overused tropes charming as they are being played in a sincere way. 
To sum it all up: Disgaea’s design and story are wacky, but in the good kind of way.

[h1]Tactical JRPG? Sounds Basic[/h1] 
The gameplay of Disgaea is really simple, I want to remind you that the original game was released on the PS2 and even felt dated back then. Disgaea follows suit by giving you main characters and a lot of deep systems that you can either embrace or just ignore to fight through maps that always can be selected for grind. Disgaea is in terms of the actual gameplay stays exceedingly simple. 
And then you get to the systems behind the curtain of a simple tactical JRPG:
Item World, specialists, affinity, classes, learning, jumping, throw chains, chain explosions, senate and the respective bill calculations… Yes, the demons have a senate that you can influence by increasing your demon rank in fighting exams to pass bills by abusing the corruption of senators by handing them wanted items. This is madness.
While this sounds like too much, it is perfect. The main story of Disgaea is fun, but breaking the game is an equal part and has shaped the identity of the series for every later entry. By abusing these systems it is possible to reach extremely high numbers and near unlimited strength. 
Breaking the game, finding out what works and what doesn’t, experimenting with the systems, this is just really enjoyable. Disgaea becomes a puzzle to be solved and every system is a variable for your curiosity. Otherwise the insane endgame that is around 100 times harder (this time not a hyperbole in any form) would be impossible.
This means that main campaign of like 20 hours is just the tip of the iceberg. The side content can easily make you clock in 200 hours and more (which is absolutely optional).

[h1]Unimpressing Cover[/h1] 
The presentation is absolutely minimalistic. While the sprites carry a lot of character, they are too pixelated. While the dialogue is good, the visual representation could be cardboard and nothing would change. Decent music, but overusing the same tracks.
Production values of any NIS game are always below average from what I could gather and it has become a distinctive style, a symbol of their brand. I get the idea and I would be lying that there is nothing to it. But it just does not do the trick for me.

[h1]Aged Like Milk[/h1] 
So where do I start?
The game is relatively fast, but fast forward would have been great. Having to wait just to see the movement animations of every character is terrible and boring. If you have to do something like clear 100 floors in a row (this is related to an item): The game becomes a slog.
The graphics are absolutely blown away by the Switch version which lazily swapped some sprites from newer games, but looks that a lot better in comparison. 
Skipping animations is included in the Switch and PS4 version and the ability to increase Exp gains more. The last one sounds like cheating, but to explain to you how grindy this game can be: 
I used a program to repeat inputs I, just to reach max level on characters. Still: reaching max level with it would take around 10 hours of just letting it run. Atrocious and just too much. Cutting that time to a third is absolutely right in this case as there are no meaningful inputs. 
To make this paragraph short: Don’t read the Switch and PS4 upgrades, they would just ruin your day. And stay away from the mobile version, it is even better.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1] 
Disgaea PC is and feels old, despite that I could enjoy the experience and time I spent with it. The main story is good, the endgame grind … is it’s own thing which can be entertaining, if one wants to learn how to calculate optimal EXP gains depending on time and method (which I did).
At least play the main campaign, it isn't grindy and has a decent story. Everything else is considered to be a bonus.

You must be thinking "71 hours and can't recommend? Well I actually first heard about Disgaea Hour of Darkness in a gaming magazine back in 2003. The article was titled "The Best RPG you've never heard of." As a huge Final Fantasy Tactics fan I had to check it out. I immediately fell in love. Started skipping school to play it in my closet. I moved my TV and PS2 into my walk in closet and my parents were none the wiser. I even laughed reading "You know you've played too much Disgaea when..." 

So here's the deal. It's the same game I played 17 years ago. Normally that's a good thing. But not in this case it's a terrible thing. So many QoL improvements that have come in sequels is completely missing. Hell it's missing all the QoL from Disgaea 1 Complete. Sure it is a fraction of the cost, with 3x the grind necessary. I guess when I was 16 hundreds of hours on a game was amazing. So much bang for my buck. Now I am dad and work 40+ hours a week. It's much harder to sink that much time in as often. About 20 hours in I cashed in my Google Play Rewards and bought Disgaea 1 Complete for Android. What took me 71 hours only took me 19 on Disgaea 1 Complete. 

Things that are missing from the game.
Updated sprites and maps
CHEAT SHOP
Strongest Enemies Bill
Weakest Enemies Bill
"Etna Mode is unlocked by default on the title screen, without the need for codes to be entered.
Fully touch based controls, similar to Disgaea DS. (MEH)
Auto Battle, which allows you to select any number of characters who automatically deploy on the following level. (HELPS WITH THE GRIND)
Repeat Battle, which allows the game to automatically restart playing a previously completed story level.
A new speed option, from x1 to x8 speed, for stages. (AMAZING!)
A quick menu for the hub area, unlocked by completing the first chapter of Story Mode or Etna Mode.
You are able to make a single cloud save, which can be recalled on any other device.
Cheat Shop is now available in the Dark Assembly allowing the player to modify multiple attributes of the game, such as EXP gain, enemy level, Item World stages and more."

So while I still love Disgaea, it is hard to recommend this version of the game. Wait for Complete or play it on Switch/PS4/Android.

I've played this game on DS and got it again a while back in a fit of nostalgia when it went on sale, then basically just didn't touch it. Now that I am playing it again, I am remembering more of the bad along with the good.

The general TRPG of it all is great; the battles are sometimes frustrating, and sometimes require some lateral thinking or strategy you don't prefer.

The Disgaea specific shortcomings are amplified these days though - this game is all about the grind, and the grind certainly isn't as pleasurable as it was the first time through. Item World is often a dull path through difficult to navigate maps which you can't leave except every 10 consecutive battles (unless you have a special item). Some of the story battles don't seem to scale well with the other challenges and it's easy to over level and suck all the challenge out of them.

Overall, it is still definitely a good game, but mostly in the context of being an older game these days. With that in mind, I just can't recommend it (unless you have a chance to pick it up for free!) - there's too many other good games to play these days!

I have not played a Disgaea game before this one and i've barely played an SRPG before, so my perspective is of a person getting into SRPG's with this as their first game. I'll talk about this game both in terms of the main story and the post game.

As far as the main story goes, this is quite a challenging little game. You are encouraged to form your own diverse team and come up with their roles based on their strengths weaknesses and weapon proficiencies. You find yourself forming strategies with units throwing other units, disabling hazards for the team or barricading more vurnerable but powerful units. You can pass the game with little knowledge and even using exclusively main characters rather than created ones, it is all up to you. In addition to this you can even boost your equipment by entering them and playing through them as randomly generated dungeons, which is a fun feature. The characters are charmingly obnoxious and a good amount of the music is enjoyable. It doesn't take particularly long to beat the main story, but it is certainly a challenge the first time through. You may even need to grind a bit or you may simply feel the need to improve your team.

Of course if you develop a taste for grinding and improving your team, you're gonna end up in the post game with the rest of us degenerates! Seriously though, it isn't a mandatory part of the experience, but it can be very satisfying. The main issue with it is that it is far from accessible unless you are prepared. Almost none of the absolutely critical post game grind is explained in the game. This is also where some of the strategy elements taper off. You find yourself spamming the most powerful moves with high coverage over and over. People say that it becomes a meta strategy thing where the goal is to identify the quickest ways to level and exploit the system to gain ultimate power in record time! Which is complete nonsense because 0.0% of the people who play the post game did it without using guides. It's a minefield of what you *must* do and *must not* do that keeps you from achieving powerful characters in any reasonable amount of time. You could very easily waste hundreds of hours of time doing your own thing when an alternate strategy is five times more effective in half the time. So if you choose to walk this path, read the levelling guides, get armsmasters, get statisticians, never have more than ten active members, always upgrade your weapons and don't use majins because thats cheating! 

So basically if you want a solid SRPG for a little bit, you're good. If you want an unhealthy obsession and you crave ever higher numbers, welcome home.

Overall charming characters, cool story that has a few emotional points (feels like a classic jrpg narratively, and not an anime), honestly some of the cooler tactics style games in the industry (a genre that is under-represented nowadays), and just worth playing if you like tactics, anime, jrpg, fantasy, or watching damage and health numbers go up in humongous ways.

Forewarning: this is NOT Disgaea 1 Complete! This is a PC port of the PS2 port, Disgaea: Afternoon of Darkness. As far as I can tell, aside from the text, the only noticeable graphical improvements between this and previous ports are character artwork for dialogue/icons, and of course a solid chunk (but not all) text is rendered through system fonts.

BUT THAT'S NOT A BIG DEAL. Complete is literally a port of this port, and even when it goes on sale it's quite a bit more expensive ($25 on Switch at the time of this writing, and that's literally them trying to get ppl into the series after the D6 reveal). the Pretty Prinny mod is a MUST with this (still unfinished, v0.5 at the time of this writing, but all the important stuff is done) but aside from that, only reason to take the steep price difference is if you plan on playing the Switch port on the go, or if you just REALLY dont find the charm in the original sprites (Pretty Prinny allows you to disable the sprite filtering like in the D2 PC port)

Despite the people complaining about this not being Complete, aside from graphics, it's basically the same. As the first game in the series, it can be kinda rough coming back to this when you're more familiar with the smoother experiences (faster turns, smoother menuing, not risking coming into an unfinishable floor in Item World after hours of grinding, etc) of later games, but again, none of these things are present in Complete either. it's JUST a graphical update. If you've lost your original PS2/PSP version of the game and want to re-experience the best story in the series (or want to catch yourself up before playing DD2, D5 or the upcoming D6) and if you're okay with the drawbacks, $15 aint a bad price, because AGAIN, Complete isn't the overhaul you think it is.
