Disgaea is a long-running & well known series at this point, but how does the original, the game that started it all, hold up 17 years later?
I'm pleased to say that after re-playing this game for the first time in years, with full nostalgia glasses to the side, that this is still one of the most quirky, fun, and enjoyable Strategy RPGs of all time.
The characters are well-designed and well-thought out, luckily straying from the typical one-sided cliches that most developers latch on to when making these types of games.
The graphics may slightly hold the game back, as there wasn't much that they couldn't have done on the PS1 that they did on the PS2, but the over-all aesthetics and designs of both the main characters, enemies, and recruitable demons, as well as the other plethora of characters that can be created, became a house aesthetic in the series, as these were the designs they would base every game they made after on.
A lot of complaints for this era of RPGs (the early 2000's) was voice acting, as besides Final Fantasy X, most Japanese-to-English dubs of RPGs being ported in during this time ranged from acceptable to atrocious.
I was pleasantly surprised that the voice acting & overall humor & script of this game still holds up today.
There may be a few outdated jokes here or there, and a couple of cringe-worthy lines that weren't much better in 2002, but generally the humor and charm lands 99% of the time and the character development is a slow burn to a fantastic finish.
As for the gameplay, if you've ever played an SRPG, you already know what this entails. Choose where to move, ready your attacks, and execute.
Regardless, you'll need to think every move through, as you have to consider enemy placements for skills, team attacks, and Geographical buffs and debuffs as you fight your way through the 40-hour-on-average main story.
There are parts in the game where you'll hit a brick wall, and the one small flaw of this game peeks through.
This game is a grind. And you will be grinding a LOT. For players who are used to this, this is just another enjoyable aspect of the game, but for those who thought they could breeze through the game for the story, you're in for a rude awakening.
You'll play the first few stages of each chapter with relative ease, and then come to a surprising halt as they ramp up the difficulty for the boss stage.
However, the gameplay and depth are still so enjoyable, I never found myself remiss of the grinding.
With options such as Item World, Dark Assembly, and being able to replay any stage you've unlocked so far, you'll find your favorite way of grinding relatively easily and you can get lost in these, not even realizing you've already grinded your way up 5 to 10 levels.

In summary, Disgaea won "Best RPG No One Played" in 2002 when it debuted, and now it's a mainstay series that any hardcore RPG fan would gush about.
If you're new to the series, this is a great jumping off point, as these characters also show up in almost every future Disgaea game, and you'll happily be recruiting them for many years to come.
I'm glad they turned this Hour of Darkness, into Years of Darkness, and I'll see you in the Netherworld.

Disgaea, an interesting gem of a game that isn't always the most polished, but undeniably is one of a kind and a treat to experience.

I originally discovered this series during a time period in my life where I didn't have internet, on that day where I had nothing new to play on my computer, I discovered an older game in my possession called "Makai Kingdom", and from there my fascination for the series grew. I really enjoyed the overall aesthetic of the game, as well as the gameplay mechanics and things itself, it was an old game, but somehow so unique and fresh in concepts. It combined a make your own party adventure along with a set cast for an enjoyable story and remarkable game experience. Needless to say after falling in love with that, I looked into more of the franchise, and saw that there were handful of games on steam, and as you'd expect, Disgaea, much like Makai Kingdom, did not fail me on any of those wistful notes of passion.

The game in and of itself is a fever dream of an experience, from outrageous anime antics, to memorable characters with funny stories, to just the insane numbers crunching that these games pull out of you if you go for the fabled 100% completion. With lots of tie ins from other games made by the developers, to fun character classes you discover and build up, or just the absolute insanity of trying to get some of the achievements, there is clearly a lot of passion this game had in it's creation. Not to mention passion from the community, as there are plenty of guides and walkthroughs on this game that boil everything down to the last detail to help you get to the grand conclusion. It is nothing short of crazy, just how deep the love goes for this series, and it makes me very excited to move forward in the series since my completion of this game was literally minutes ago.

That being said, while a fantastic experience, the game does have some flaws (for me), that definitely made me happier to be done sooner than later. The main story of the game can be blown through fairly easily, without too much grinding and what not, but if you really want to go for the big gold sticker of achievements, and don't know much about the series, just know it's gonna be a looooong road. Now while not completely a flaw in it's own right, it is obviously very much a tedious thing that is not going to be for everyone, and even for myself who really enjoys grinding in games (if it had a clear payoff, which this game does for sure), there are limits even to what I can absorb. The game is also quite old, with a lot of slow hud and directioning, even once you have it down, that adds a bit to the time frame of the game and can slowly drain your brain. I had to take a few breaks on the cleanup of this game, because as much as I enjoyed, it started to get real slow and I just couldn't take it without a little bit of a cool off. Especially when it came to item world grinds, as much as I enjoyed items and all those systems, if I have to see the item world ever again it'll be too soon, oh and passing bills in the assembly, that too was very draining. Map repeating could be faster as well, but still not the worst!

All and all, even with the slowness and super long attention span you have to have to complete a game like this, the payoff is fairly good. It's fun to go from a few numbers to being able to destroy everything with the press of a button. The mechanics are fun, the story is cute, and the characters and designs of everything are really a treat. The polish of the game is definitely exemplary, from music, to even the animations, and especially the art. The art of Disgaea is iconic, and probably what most people would identify it by, even with my few games experience, when I see this art I know where it's coming from. Needless to say, I had a blast and I definitely recommend this game to other people that enjoy building up your band of crazy demons as you blast through the madness that is the Disgaea universe.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#481 out of 633)... it's time for Disgaea PC.

It's Disgaea! One of the quintessential SRPGs! The fact that this game has been ported to so many platforms after its original PS2 release (by my count, it's available on PS3, PS4, NDS, NS and PC) should be more than sufficient evidence that it's a game well-worth your time.

That said, there are caveats. While the story remains as engaging and amusing as it ever was (especially thanks to the extra optional content and alternate endings) the fundamental mechanics of play have not exactly aged well. Over the years, the Disgaea series has introduced numerous quality-of-life improvements and additions. This process occurred so slowly and subtly that if you were playing the games as they released, you might not even notice the differences. But comparing the first Disgaea game here to the most recent, Disgaea 5, its readily apparent that things have changed immensely.

The core problem, simply, is that relative to its successors, Disgaea is a bit clumsy and limiting. You have fewer options in combat, and must endure much more inventory management. Also, perhaps most damningly, there are fewer options to circumvent the standard grind. One of the more interesting elements of the Disgaea series as it stands today is the "gaming" of the level system. With a level cap of 9999, playing normally most players will likely die of,old age before getting close. Thus most games incorporate a number of different tactics and tricks to make leveling easy. If you know what you're doing in a modern Disgaea game, you can gain several hundred levels in a matter of minutes. Unfortunately this aspect of the series does not manifest as strongly in the first two games, so grinding to the appropriate levels for postgame content can be prohibitively tedious.

Even so, Disgaea remains a classic for good reason. The characters and humor alone justify playing through the game at least once, while mechanically its a far cry from its successors, the SRPG genre itself is so stubbornly resistant to change that I doubt many genre fans will take issue. So think of these criticisms simply as forewarning to those unacquainted with the genre.

And for the faithful, Disgaea PC incorporates all of the additional "extra" content from the handheld ports, making it the definitive version of,the game. I've heard that's there's also a mod that replaces the sprites with HD versions, spthough i haven't tried it myself, so there's little reason to play the more expensive (and, among fans, divisive) "remastered" version instead.

Note: also played on Sony Playstation 2 and Sony Playstation Portable.

71761741.review:
Disgaea is an addictive, fun, challenging grindfest. It's all about raising numbers and it rarely has been so satisfying to do that. You can put countless hours into upgrading your weapons and armor, you can enchant them with the abilities and boosts you want and there's a ton more of optional or hidden content. Not all of it works flawless and sometimes it can be frustrating, for one reason or the other.

1. [b][u]Story mode:[/u][/b] Fully linear, no choices. The different endings depend on easily to miss and hidden requirements like killing certain characters on a map/battle or losing to them. They also depend on whether or not you had friendly kills.
2. [b][u]Grind mode:[/u][/b] The main way to improve your items is the Item World. A randomly generated world where you get bonus stats on your Item for each cleared floor. But the generator fails at times and puts enemies on spots you can't reach. Fortunatelly the exit to the next floor is always accessable, so you will just have to accept not clearing some levels from time to time and missing bonus stats as well as the rewards for clearing the floor (Exp, money or items).
3. [b][u]Dark assembly and shops:[/u][/b] The next huge chapter where you can spend much time and money. In order to improve the selection and quality of the shop items you can buy, you will have to deal with the dark assembly. There you can raise your influence, unlock new options and bribe senators to be able to apply said options. But all the bribing is pretty pointless because the game just keeps introducing more and stronger senators. You can - in theory - also fight them to force a decision. But with some of the senators being over 100 levels stronger than your characters, that's... not something that is going to happen anytime soon.
4. [b][u]Combat system:[/u][/b] Disgaea features the by far most advanced enemy AI I've ever experienced. Enemies will always try to get the best position and do the most damage. They will unleash skills in the most efficient way and aim for your vulnerable characters whenever possible.
The maps can be hard and often require planning ahead. Where are the main targets and goals? Which is the best way to get there and how many turns does it take? Do you need a stack of 3 or 4 characters to increase their reach? Miscalculations pay dearly, for they'll leave you open to attacks.
5. [b][u]Leveling up characters:[/u][/b] At first and for some time it will take much effort and time to level up new characters, because they are so weak, you lack the equipment to change that and they need to land the killing blow to gain experience. Which is especially painful for healers. The best course of action is to ignore character creation until you got a hang of the basics and some decent stuff together. With the proper gear equipped, leveling up characters goes a lot smoother.
6. [b][u]Play time/Replay value:[/u][/b] The story has a decent length, but 90% of the ~160 hours I spent on my first playthrough was grinding levels and gear. Once you have finished the game you get the option to save and start a new "cycle", which means that you can keep all characters, levels and gear. Of course you can always just skip it and start anew from scratch, if that's your thing. But I'm grateful for being able to go through the game at a much faster pace this time, for I doubt I'd be willing to put that much time and effort into Disgaea again, just to see the other endings.

But with things as they are, I look forward to see what more the game has to offer. Especially now that I figured many things that could have made my life a lot easier if I had known earlier. Like throwing senators or that the Dark Cannon has an autofire option if you just keep the button pressed. You don't have to mash it like crazy to fire. And it only took me 150 hours to realize that. My poor gamepad xD

70784759.review:
[b] There is something special buried somewhere deep within the mess. But at the end of the day, this is a mediocre version of a game, which fails to communicate and capitalize on its mechanics. [/b]

I got into the series with Disgaea 4 on PS3, casually playing it for about 40 hours. I never beat it, but had a great time nonetheless. I never ran into most of the issues I have with Disgaea PC, at least to the same extent, and feel that 4 was a more forgiving and balanced game.


I had heard great things about the original Disgaea and I assumed it was the simplest, most straightforward game in the series. It starts off as a fun yet complex SRPG, but eventually can devolve into madness, due to a lack of explanations and quality of life features. Played like a normal RPG Disgaea can be enjoyed for a good while, but eventually you will hit a wall and instead of coming up with a better approach or getting more skilled, you must grind, a lot. There is simply no other option to progress in the game besides grinding. The catch comes from finding how to grind most efficiently. Disgaea has very meta game design, which is awesome, but it is never really explained, and this ends up being the fatal weakness.

Right off the bat the game is more or less lying by omission. I thought I understood the game. I’d talked to the informational NPCs and even skimmed through a beginners guide here on Steam. However, I was unaware of the near mandatory nature of Statisticians when grinding, thus 40+ hours into the game I realized that I was playing it “wrong” and had wasted my time. I had also frequently used a Prinny, which despite being a character the game starts you with, becomes basically unusable as you progress. From that point on I decided to use Cheat Engine in hopes of rebalancing my playthrough. I typically avoid cheating in skill based games, unless I’ve already beat them, but Disgaea is not exactly a skill based game. Disgaea is a skinner box game with exponentially growing requirements. Which probably sounds awful, but if you play correctly, using the meta mechanics to fight back and make the game work in your favor, the Disgaea formula can be one of the most strategic and rewarding in all video games. Played incorrectly... you will hit a breaking point and either have to stop or cheat.

The lack of information and quality of life features is present throughout most of the series, but this first one is especially bad. Plus the item world, starting roster, character creation, healing, etc. are all broken in some way.  


Gameplay aside, the goofy depiction of the netherworld was always fun! The visual design and music turn dark and grim clichés on their heads, creating a memorable and unique aesthetic. The three main characters all range from great to annoying at times. They clash constantly which leads to some entertaining moments and a good joke every now and then, but they can also feel like hyper anime archetypes sometimes. As for the story, it starts off good with an equally goofy and compelling premise, but as it goes there are some poorly executed twists, melodrama, and bad pacing which really brings it down in the second half.  Surprisingly there are multiple endings too, but they are implemented so strangely that nobody would ever know what determines an ending, even after getting one.

At one point in the game there is a cut-scene where the main cast of characters do a team attack to break an “invincible” barrier. I don't understand why the player could not have been in control during this sequence, it would have made for an awesome level. This was the moment I realized just how much missed potential was in Disgaea. And this missed potential is found in every facet of the game. If they would have made performing team attacks between the characters with opposing views, like Laharal and Flonne, integral to leveling up, or at least stronger than spamming special attacks, they could have delivered a more contextualized experience and added another layer of strategy. This also affects the level design, which is very underwhelming considering the potential all the mechanics allow for.


I would not recommend Disgaea PC, however I would cautiously recommend the series as a whole. If you really want to get into the Disgaea games, do some research on the deeper mechanics and choose one of the newer games.

[h1]The Ultimate Weeb Fuel[/h1]
[i]I remember playing this game back in the PSP days, and this PC port does a fairly good job in doing it justice. But let's examine it in order...[/i]

[h1][b]PROs[/b][/h1]

- [b]Addicting gameplay[/b]. It may be monotonous for some, but if you happen to like it, it will keep you glued to your screen: there aren't half measures, you either love it or hate it. 

- [b]The strategy factor is very simplistic[/b], almost non-existent, yet despite this the game still manages to be a blast to play. That of course is yet another strength point which can be a weakness depending on the player.

- [b]Original mechanics[/b]. For example, there's a council where you can pass new laws which will benefit your team... However, corruption is a daily occurrence in the Netherworld, and some of those nasty demon politics will approve the stuff you propose them only if you manage to give them what they want; again, this is just an example: the game is filled with interesting features.

- [b]Lots of replayability[/b] due to the fact that there's a good amount of dungeons and challenges, but mostly because there's lots of grinding. If you like this aspect of the game, you'll find bread for your teeth. If not, stay miles away.

[h1][b]CONs[/b][/h1]

- [b]Debatable plot[/b]. The premise of the story could be interesting, and it might work even if it's demential... The issue is that it's way too silly, at the point of becoming cringeworthy. Also, it's predictable, and filled to the brim with cliches and stereotyped characters; but you know... These kind of games are often like that, and who the hell plays Disgaea for the plot anyway.

- [b]Lazy overall design[/b]. The world you play in is actually very immersive, my grudge would be in how repetitive it is. Usually, the dungeons aren't that inspiring (fire caves, ice caves, forests, that kind of stuff), and they're massively recycled too... Like, ad nauseam. And you must replay them a lot or else you won't be able to fight lots of damage sponges. This is also true regarding the enemies: often they're just palette swaps. But anyway, I guess I'm used to this kind of stuff, especially in JRPGs. I saw way worse [*points at Compile Heart*]

-[b]Some skills break the game[/b]. I don't know if that's intended, but some of your characters have some spells which are way too strong in my opinion.

- [b]The soundtrack[/b]. This is a nitpick more than anything, but still. Due to the grindy nature of the game, you'll soon find yourself disabling the music. It does fit the tone of the game, but it becomes rather repetitive sooner or later.

This is a game I picked up, gave up on, and then came back to, and knowing the basics the second time around made the second playthrough the first real playthrough. I've got 90 hours logged in this game, but actually I'm at the gates of Celestia, or in otherwords near the end of the main story but only at a toes depth into the real meat of the game, the end game content.

Disgaea doesn't feel like a book, or like a movie, or like a pen and paper role playing game, or like anything other than a video game.  In terms of gameplay it also doesn't feel much like a turn based game either, even though it is. Disgaea amps up the pace of gameplay compared to other strategy RPGs, thanks to the way turn orders are handled in the most simple possible way and thanks to the especially tactile lifting system, which has nothing to do with muscles or with petty retail theft.

At the time Disgaea was released in the west very few strategy rpgs had ever been localized. Fire Emblem and Advance Wars from Nintendo had only recently made their localized debuts. To most fans of rpgs in the west, Final Fantasy Tactics on the PS1 was still considered the gold standard of the genre. Which is kind of ridiculous, because Final Fantasy Tactics though a charming game was also a game with permadeath and incredibly tedious grinding in which it was possible to get stuck in an unwinnable gamestate hours in and have to restart your file, if you didn't have a backup save. Or reload every death, but then why should the game even have permadeath. The English translation was also very bland and confusing.

In a lot of ways Disgaea is the polar opposite of Final Fantasy Tactics, the first 20 hours made up entirely of short cakewalk levels with amusing and funny designs and high novelty value. Grinding is also streamlined. Assuming you learn how to grind properly without looking it up, or look it up (the game winks and nudges you towards how you should grind efficiently but never outright spills it), the main storyline won't present much of a challenge until the last few chapters, making the novelty factor the main draw. The story also falls off pretty hard around the time most people who don't figure out how to grind would give up on the game. Lets just say the story doesn't go in a direction which is interesting if you like the main cast and setting of the game and since the main cast as setting of the game is very very strong most players will. Isn't this why Metal Gear Solid 2 wasn't popular?!

This is the second Disgaea game I've played, the first being Disgaea 5 on the Nintendo Switch. While Disgaea 1 PC has rather rough gameplay compared to the super polished and refined combat found in Disgaea 5, it quickly didn't matter as I became sucked into the storyline and its colorful cast of characters. 

Disgaea PC follows Laharl, the demon prince of the Netherworld as he wakes up from a 2 year nap and learns that his father has passed away. With his vassal Etna, Laharl fights to claim the throne as Overlord. Things get complicated as angel trainee Flonne and a group of humans arrive in the Netherworld. Why was an angel sent to assassinate a demon? What are humans doing in the Netherworld? Why is there a robot? At some point you'll just begin accepting the bizarre things that are happening and fall in love with the story like I did.

There are also lots of job classes to experiment with: from cute witches to exploding penguins, there's a lot of possible teams to set up. Want a team of ninjas? Go for it! The apprentice system in particular is handy, as it lets you teach spells and skills to units that would normally not learn them, meaning that everyone could have healing spells if you wanted. There's just so much customization to suit your play style.

However, as this is a Nippon Ichi Software game, I must warn you that this is a very grindy game. The level cap is Lv9999, but you'll really need to be around Lv70-100 to beat the main storyline (my team was around Lv80-89). The grinding isn't too bad, but if it's something you dislike in a RPG, this might not be the game for you. However, you might get addicted to the grind after awhile, and find yourself going to the Item World instead of continuing the plot!

Would you buy a quirky game about becoming the Overlord of hell?

Disgaea has a very accessible storyline that scratches a boardgamer's itch for tactics. It also has ridiculous villains and mechanics like throwing monsters at eachother or stacking your team into a tower to toss across the map.

Beneath all the cutesy art and the storyline you can finish after a few days of play, there's a really beautiful levelling-up and optimization metagame to enjoy. There's a variety of endgame content and you can grind for stats over 9000. Have you ever wanted to cross-train your characters? There's even a teacher/pupil system that lets your mages teach your ninjas how to cast magic. Have you ever wanted to tweak the game's difficulty? Bribe other demons in the Dark Assembly to approve your choices.

I recommend disgaea to people who really enjoyed other Tactical RPGs like Final Fantasy Tactics or Vandal Hearts. Not a game for everybody, but it's fun and challenges you to solve combat like a puzzle and break the stat system.

53951229.review:
Grinding is simply the name of the game in Disgaea and I'm still not sure why I enjoy it as much as I do. In most cases, I'm not the biggest fan of grinding and any excessive grind requirement in a game is usually enough to turn me off from it unless it is particularly done well and supported by other mechanics. So why do I have well over 100 hours in this game and why am I excited to play the sequels? Ut seems that the answer to that is simply that the developers built the game from the ground up with the intention of making the grind fun.

There are a number of ways to grind in Disgaea and by combining them you can create an exceptionally powerful group of characters. The "classic" grind is the obvious one where you defeat enemies to level up your characters and unlock a plethora of new classes, some of which are new, others of which are upgrades of jobs you already have. This is a pretty standard RPG mechanic and is fun enough with abilities that are unlocked but then you start the realize where the game gets weird. You also unlock the ability to enter any piece of equipment that you get your hands on, whether it be a sword, a shield, or a piece of food, and battle through it like it were a dungeon. Each cleared floor along the way strengthens the item by increasing its stats and allowing you to transfer its stats to other items if you so wish. You wouldn't think that the combination of these mechanics would be as fun as they are but I've become a believer.

This all comes with a disclaimer from me, though; I am not a fan of a number of the design choices in the game but all of these are outside of the primary focus of Disgaea. The story and characters, on a narrative level, didn't appeal to me and neither did the art style of the game; it's very anime. Fortunately, you become numb to these aspects as you dive deeper into the progression of your characters and items and only vaguely remember that there was a campaign to begin with. 

I recommend this game to tactical RPG fans who enjoy leveling characters and upgrading equipment as well as those who enjoy managing a roster of characters. I suggest you stay away if grinding and progression doesn't appeal to you or if you are unable to get past the silly anime graphics and story.

53628505.review:
The only game I've tried where grinding is actually fun! 

You might say that "grinding" is what this game is really about, but it's really about creative ways to improve your band of cutesy demon monster people. 

You'll be inventing new ways to go through to the incredibly huge level cap, things that would in any other game be considered "cheesing" or outright "cheating"- these are just normal ways to play Disgaea. 
The mechanics are very well thought out, with some unique stuff that can be difficult to learn at the beginning, but when things "click" and you understand how various mechanics fit together, you'll be running around gleefully cheesing your way through the game. 
You'll be bribing senators, making huge geo-panel combos, entering your own items from the inventory as actual dungeons to find and subdue their denizens to work for you, and murdering hordes of enemies with incredibly overpowered, flashy special attacks.
You'll be throwing guys over obstacles, throwing monsters into monsters to combine their stats into super-monsters, and then defeat said monsters for even more experience and power due to the decrees that give experience multipliers because you bribed the council into allowing it... 

Phew, the list goes on and on, and seemingly never ends.

And then there's story mode, which, as a NPC is quick to point out, doesn't require much knowledge of the game mechanics to complete. Fully voice acted in both English and Japanese, with visual novel-like level intros and dialogue, with wacky characters and slightly crazy hijinks.

And then there's the audio/visual presentation, which is just fabulous, especially if you consider this is an old, old, OLD Playstation 2 game. The music is fantastic, with themes you can listen to over and over without ever becoming bored, and the master-level pixel-art animations combined with low-polygon, subtle backdrops creates a very pleasant combination to look at.

Full, unadulterated recommendations for Disgaea. I can't wait to "finish" it and move on to the sequel!

53282418.review:
Where to begin...

[Story]
It starts off with a narration about what has happened to the Main Character Laharl's father. After learning about, this he embarks on a quest to become the new overlord. Along the way he'll meet a very fun and quirky cast of characters that you'll have fun with the entire time. It's one of those stories that are ridiculous and comical in one chapter, then goes straight into serious and sad the next, but it all flows well and comes into one cohesive story. Oh, and if you like hidden endings, they have that too. Not much to say here without spoilers but suffice it to say, you'll enjoy the story.

[Graphics]
Being that this is a game that was made back in 2004, then ported to the PSP and then finally here, the graphics are fine for what they are, but don't exactly expect HD sprites that look as good as something like Jotun for example. This isn't exactly a fair comparison, but the game is starting to show a bit of age. However, the old UI does give it a classic look that you may enjoy.

[Performance]
You might be wondering how a game with a radeon hd 5750 as it's recommended GPU has performance issues, and you'd be right. It's not actually low framerates that are the issue, it's that for some reason in any cutscene where there is some audio playing in the background (such as an alarm) while the characters are talking, it causes the audio to skip like a scratched CD and the framerate tanks. To be fair it's a low framerate on still images and only happens like 4 times in the entire 24ish hour story, but the audio issues still exist and they crop up on new game+ to be experienced all over again.
 
[Gameplay]
Here we get to the meat of the game. There's just too much to describe here and I love it. Whether you're stacking up all the enemies in the level to fight an enemy hundreds of levels above you for massive XP, bribing and killing your senators to get your way, farming clones on an item world level in order to kill enough monsters to make your own in the dark assembly, or trying to get skills from your pupils there's so much to do. I can't say if the mechanics are amazing as this is my first strategy RPG but from what I can tell it is very good as there is so many ways you could go about playing so it never feels like it's repetitive, and it doesn't suffer from a lack of game modes and content.

Now you might hear that this is a grind heavy game, and this is true. However, the grind in this game is different from every other game. On one hand, it isn't even necessary to complete the game. By default the game gives enough xp for you to beat it without ever needing to use anything other than the most basic of systems. However the end game content is what you'd grind to complete. For example, in a classic RPG, you would run around in a circle and one-shot mindless enemies for a couple hours until you could beat the boss. In this game, you'd 

1.spend a couple hours farming "statisticians" to earn 4x exp per kill 
2. try to bribe/kill your way into getting a triple XP bill passed so that you can kill one enemy for massive xp
3. then you'd have to go into the map and stack the enemies up to get a high level enemy while carefully managing your characters so that nobody dies because you can only kill one enemy per triple xp bill bonus and that applies to the enemies too. You must also make sure that the character you're trying to level will be the one to do the final blow or they wont level.

It sounds tedious, but there is much more fun to be had exploring the randomly generated item world and trying to optimize so that it takes less time to gather all of the statisticians. And after you do all that, the payout is huge as you can easily jump 50+ levels in one battle. Takes time to set up but it provides a much more interesting gameplay loop. Im trying to keep this brief but grinding in this game is actually fun because it takes real thought and has variety instead of mindlessly using earthquake and going to the pokemon center 1000 times in a row.

Score 9/10. It doesn't earn a perfect score because of the previously mentioned audio issues im having, but it doesn't seem like it's a widespread issue so YMMV. Either way, a solid recommendation

50443383.review:
Disgaea was always a series I heard in passing. "That one series where you can grind to Lv 9999". Aside from that, its art style, and that they're turn based tactics games, I didn't know much about the series. So, when the opportunity arose, I purchased it, eager to discover what this series was for myself. After putting a lot of time into the game, I figure "I'll review it." So here it is.

So, the game begins with a short narration, describing the basic plot of the game. You play as the scrawny, arrogant demon Prince Laharl, heir to the throne of the Netherworld. He awoke from a 2-year sleep to find that his father has been dead, and the Netherworld has gone to chaos due to the king's death and his own hibernation. Dismayed and eager to show everyone who's in charge he sets out to prove his worth and claim the proper title of "Overlord". He's accompanied by a sarcastic and sinister vassal "Etna" and an angel with a hard on for love "Flonne". Together, along with a few other characters, they make the story of Disgaea. Now while it sounds like the potential for a serious story, for a lot of the game it's not. 

A lot of the dialogue, character interactions, and story beats are more comedic in nature. The story does have a semblance of character growth and development with the main cast and the stakes do get raised in the latter half of the game, but it still has a focus on the comedy. It does cause some tonal whiplash (especially in Chapter 9 which came after a somber character moment and before the game starts focusing on a more coherent and serious story in with greater stakes.) but for the most part I think it works well. I especially enjoy the comedy. What makes it even better for me are the transitions between chapters. They're called "Episodes" with a preview of what's to come with a short narration by Etna, often exaggerating things for the sake of humor, which to me feels like it belongs from an anime from the late 1990's. This in tandem with the other humor makes for a story I can get some laughs from.

I've spent time talking on the story, but to be honest story (and story levels) only accounts for a small portion of the game. For context, the game is touted as one where you can reach level 9999, but in the story, you can be the beat the game with a well-balanced team at around lv 65. 

You see, the real meat and potatoes of the game are in its post-game, a giant grind fest dedicated to improving levels and stats to tackle end-game challenges that at their lowest range from around levels 100-200, while the high end bosses are at levels that reach into the thousands. Now that sounds like the main campaign is dwarfed in scope and length compared to the extra content, and in a sense it is. I'd also point out though that the main story can take around 20-25 hours to beat, which for RPG length hits a length that isn't too long but isn't too short either though I'm sure opinions on length vary.

But what might those "meat and potatoes" of the gameplay be? Well, to simply put it, this is a turn-based tactics game. You select characters (up to 10 can be on the battlefield at once), move them around a tiled map, and kill everything you see. As you kill enemies, you gain 3 types of "currency". "Experience" which levels you up and increases your stats, "Hell" the equivalent of money which you use to buy items, and "Mana" which is used to perform actions in the Dark Assembly. The Dark Assembly being a place where you spend "mana" for things like creating new characters, unlocking new areas, adding and improving to the item shops, and more. Though a criticism I have for it is that it's up to rng whether those bills would pass. So, pray to the demons prepare for a lot of soft resting to pass them, which doesn't even work all the time because some bills are just about impossible to pass without pulling an Emperor Palpatine and just "becoming the senate".

Switching gears from discussing gameplay, I'd like to mention the graphics and sound. The interesting thing is that this was an enhanced version of a PSP game, so unfortunately HD sprites aren't available which is a disappointment since later games had high res sprites that looked amazing. Even as is though, the sprites are still well made with plenty of detail and expressiveness in their idle poses and attack animations. Laharl for example has his signature scarf flowing constantly which looks great. There are a couple of options for the sprites so if you want clearer sprites or fuzzier ones you can have them too. I felt a bit mixed about the sprites, but the artwork and portraits are more hit and miss to me. The series trademark art style wasn't in the first game, so you won't be seeing the usual style the series is known for. However, it does offer a style that I appreciate, being more rigid and grounded compared to the later games though it suffers from inconsistencies. (In game cuts during combo attacks are a good example)

While the graphics were a positive mixed bag, the music is thankfully more consistently great. Its soundtrack is on the smaller side, but it has several battle music tracks which helps alleviate tedium when fighting and grinding. The best tracks for me are ones you get for going for each of the game's multiple endings (Though unlocking the tracks to listen to them as much as you want is very expensive). In addition, you can select a set track to play while you explore the Item World, randomly generated dungeon that you travel through when entering an item.

One aspect that I want to mention though is performance. I usually don't talk about performance in my reviews, since it's hard to tell how much of the issue is of the game itself or how much much is due to the machine you run it on. However, after playing the sequel which can run 60 fps at all times with improved visuals, it really does make the optimization of the game seem much worse in comparison and leaves me wondering what happened. There are fixes to the issues of performance and graphics, but it still is something I feel should be brought up because it was so noticeable.

Putting aside technical issues, there are some other things I want to mention that the port has. Some of these include: New UI that can be swapped for the UI present in the original game, characters and maps that were present in the PSP version of the game, an extra mode Etna mode which is a short alternate story where you play as Etna (that has two different methods to unlock which changes the levels of the enemies you fight), and a few other odds and ends.

I think for me, the main appeal of the game isn't the art style, the anime feels or even the comedy. Don't get me wrong, I enjoy those things. Quite a bit in fact. To me though, what makes the game appealing is understanding and exploiting the game mechanics through grind and strategy to make the game bend to my knees. 

It does have issues. The story and characters can feel cliche, the presentation needed more cleaning up, and the performance was a problem that annoyed, but the rest of the experience was enjoyable enough to overcome those complaints and the story and characters were something I personally enjoyed and was invested in. If you're someone who enjoys the aesthetics and style of 90's anime I can easily recommend it to you. I'd also recommend it if you enjoy Turn Based Tactic games, or just miss the good ol days of PS2 era RPGs. I had a fantastic time playing it, and I think if you have any interest in this series this should be the game to start with.

47652146.review:
Disgaea PC might be one of the most complex turn based tactical RPG I have ever played. It combines a wide range of classes and unit types typically found in the tactical final fantasy games, with insane character levels, a unique item and loot system, unit promotions, and constant humour to make playing thoroughly enjoyable. It also introduces the concept of smart grinding. Having played Phantom Brave (which has a unique game mechanic that I didn’t like), I was apprehensive about playing this, but found the plot well structured and absurd, the voice work, music and character scripts humorous and fitting, while actually providing quite a challenge to play. That’s pretty good for a game that was originally released in 2003 for the Playstation2 and re-released for steam in 2016.

You play as Laharl, the son of the now deceased daemon king. Having slept for 2 years after your father’s death your absence has caused a power struggle amongst other daemon nobles. It’s up to you and your semi-loyal retainer Etna to try and beat some sense into any daemons who don’t bow down to your authority and deal with any other surprises on the way. And I can guarantee you won’t guess the surprises - the game takes the plot in enough weird directions that you just start to go with it after a while. The game boasts a considerable amount of endings, which take into account certain actions you preformed during your game.

Gameplay is your typical grid based combat, with the idea being to generally kill all enemies on the map. Each class of character can move different amounts and have different stats when levelling up, and some can traverse higher terrain more easily. Each class has a few different variants, with the later variants having better stats. Newer, more powerful classes might require a combination of classes to reach a certain level, or a weapon type to get to a certain proficiency level before they become available. Each class has a different proficiency with weapons, which controls how quickly they can learn special skills. Each weapon type has different attack range and some use different stats for working out damage. Attacking from the sides or behind an enemy deals more damage. You can fill up a bonus gauge by chaining attacks from multiple characters (sometimes attacking together) for bonus damage and extra items and experience at the end of battle. Sometimes there are blocks on the maps that effect some or all of the grid squares, which can be either beneficial or challenging. Characters can be picked up and thrown to move them down the map faster (sometimes making a tower of characters if they need to get from one to the other quickly), and enemies can be thrown (usually to move them or combine them into a tougher variant).

You can simply brute force your way through about 75% of the main game with minimal grinding, however that stops becoming effective at the end. This is where the smart grinding comes into play. Each and every single item has 3 levels of rarity, which can be explored in the games item world. The item world serves two purposes, firstly to level up and grind, but the main draw card is to find and defeat the specialists that reside in each item. Each specialist provides a bonus (either to direct stats, xp, weapon status effect or resistances) and rarer items can house more specialists. After they are subdued, their effect is doubled. Since these stages are traversed by getting to the exit tile you can breeze through them until you find the specialist, beat them into submission, then rush to the next level. Specialists can be combined and moved between items, so they aren’t lost when your equipment is upgraded. You also have the option of upgrading characters to other classes or a higher version of their current class. This reset them to lvl 1 and includes a % change of losing skills, but you can boost their stats when doing this, so they gain more stats every time they level up. If you repeat this then your characters can eventually reach stupid levels of hp and damage. You also have and mentor/student system, where they can learn each other techniques, which can provide many combat spells and techniques, which can make each character very versatile. All of this might seem like overkill, however it’s required for the last chapter unless you want to manually grind 10 party members to lvl 100, and essential for the new game plus content, where bosses have lvls in the 1000’s.

The characters have a fair bit of bickering and speech amongst themselves before/after each missions, which is usually very funny and sets each chapters arc. Fortunately you can skip these on stage select if your second time around, which is an excellent feature to include. Each of your castles minions are typically fairly dismissive of your chances (they are like lvl 300+) and keep in line with the tongue in cheek attitude this game has. Etna has a TV show like dialogue at the end of each chapter where she is playing out a fantasy, which is also quite funny to listen too. The soundtrack was good, suits this game very well. The voice work is well done, I didn’t find any of the voice acting grating, through the characters when fighting do use the same lines constantly.

Being a port from 2003 the game doesn’t scale as well as I hoped- it supports 1080p resolution but I had to run the game in a windowed mode to make it display correctly otherwise it looked all stretched and faded. The game seemed to develop a glitch where it would crash during special attack animation after chapter 10. The only fix I could find was to turn off the attack animation, which does have the added bonus of speeding the game up but it was disappointing to encounter. It seems that this wasn’t a straight port, as some of the original character introductions are missing or have been changed from when they were meant to appear. I did find it interesting that named characters are still getting introduced right up to the last chapter, where it is hard to kind of justify using them unless you are running a massively under levelled team.

The DLC art book gives a brief design rational behind some of the characters and has Etna and Flonne arguing, its not bad if you like this sort of thing.

If you are chasing 100% achievements then be prepared to spend a lot of time grinding. If your not willing to sink a few 100 hours into grinding, doing runs through the item world and doing a few runs through the game then this isn’t the game for you.

For more reviews please visit https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31327216/

This game has one wacky story with a mix of hilarious and ridiculous moments. It doesn't take itself too seriously with some exceptions. Disgaea is also certainly not without its band of interesting characters with some of them being completely over the top. I admit that some people might not like certain characters, so it comes down to personal preference there. The soundtrack is overall nice to listen to with some really good ones in there.

On a grand scale, one can feel overwhelmed by everything this game has to offer. If you intend to just tackle the main story of this game and casually play it, then you won't have to worry about it too much. Main storyline battles can be tough to different extents but there's many different ways you can try to succeed in each one. Like many SRPGs, there's no one way of beating the game. Just try anything and everything. As for the majority of the post-game content, I can tell you that you'll be in for a long ride if you also intend to complete everything. 

Despite my overall praise for the game, I won't say the game is flawless. For a lot of obvious reasons, this game won't be for everyone. For those who usually prefer a more serious story with strongly-developed characters, you may be disappointed if you expect that from Disgaea (although this game does have some character development). The heavy grinding in this game that's especially involved in the post-game can also be terrifying for new players who might be checking the game out. As someone who had the mindset of "Oh how long could this possibly take", I was in over my head when I began the long grind.

I come from a background of very rich and excellent turn-based strategy games. I've played every Advance Wars title, numerous Fire Emblem games, Devil Survivor 1 and 2, and even Stella Glow. 

And this game--Disgaea--is by far the WORST turn-based strategy game I have EVER played. 

It's the opposite or ergonomic, with menus that fumble and controls that simultaneously rigid and annoying. It's the inverse of intuitive, with mechanics that are both bizarre and poorly explained--a truly fun-killing combination.

The fact that you have to heal your characters in between EVERY. SINGLE. BATTLE. 
The fact that in the shop you can view your stats with a prospective purchase equipped... but not WITHOUT it equipped (in other words, there is no frame of reference).
The fact that the up/down/left/right directions are inverted to what I'm used to, and I can find no way to change them.
The fact that experience is ONLY gained by dealing the killing blow... meaning healers and weaker support attackers (like spear users) are left out to dry, as far as I know. 

Absolutely atrocious, and a complete headache all around. I may come back at some point and try to figure out a way to make this game fun, but the devs have done everything in their power to prevent this game from being an enjoyable strategic experience. Little is explained, and what IS explained is explained poorly... if that weren't bad enough, this happens to be one of THOSE games with unnecessarily complicated mechanics and ridiculous intricacies. 

Overall, I would NOT reccomend this to any fan of turn-based strategy. It throws ALL of the established conventions of the genre out the window, discarding ergonomic and intuitive design and mechanics in favor of obfuscated numbers and random stats that aren't explained. 2/10 from what I've experienced so far.

45596071.review:
Really a timeless experience. Definately has its issues but the overall experience is just as genuine after fifteen plus years.


Possibly the most comedic of all the games, at times its just back to back jokes or some form of humor in the dialogue. Has quite a couple twists, likely more then any of the other games. But at the same time, while the characters are very funny they really do not have much chemistry. They don't synergize well together from a theatrical standpoint, they're just kind of forced to be together by the plot. So only near the end does it really feel like they're a genuine social group of allied characters, up until that point there's zero sense of connectivity between them the entire time. And, while the plot has a lot of nice twists a massive amount of the story is meaningless. Most of the time, the characters are just doing relatively arbitrary things that the player will forget by the end of the game. Then only at the end do the characters end up having a distinguished consistent goal that they are working towards. 

Thus, it really only is towards the end of the game that it starts to become what all the successive games are about from start to finish; teams of allies working towards a single goal. Which is unfortunate that it takes so long for the game to collect itself, as it really does get interesting by that time. The format before then of a ramshackle trio running around doing ramshackle things, just isn't engaging and it doesn't feel like the writers had a grasp of things. But these problems are well balanced out by the amount of great twists and comedy that the story has all throughout.


The thing that genuinely damages the experience is the forced grinding. Every other chapter or so the player starts becoming out level'd by the enemies and it gradually becomes a struggle to progress. If you mess with the game and really try, you can win anyways; which does make it the most strategic of all the games at times. But eventually, enemies will just become too powerful and you have to grind and maximize your characters to progress. So every other chapter or so, ten plus minutes of pointless grinding. Which is bad enough until it starts happening in the middle of key story developments, so instead of going with the flow of the story you have to stop and grind; then can resume the story. Which really, really ruins the immersion in the plot at times.

And the item world is not much of an option, because often it will generate extremely tedious layouts that either can't be skipped or throw the player into really awkward situations. So becoming more powerful through upgrading items is not very effective during the story. The player also starts off being really underpowered, and only the characters with imperial seals equipped are able to survive during the first missions. And for some reason, the player starts off with Pleinair even though she has no business being on the team at that point and breaks the immersion of the player starting their journey just with the three protagonists. And she only has one special move, which is overly effective in general, and she starts off with an imperial seal. So the game is basically trying to trick the player into using her as a main fighter; even though she's really boring to use because of her single powerful move.

For some reason the game unlocks a lot of characters for the player, but the characters require way more mana to create then the player is ever going to have until later in the game. So a lot of the characters you will never get to use until later, at which point it's better off just sticking to the current ones instead of grinding to add a new one to the roster. Unless you're playing the game with the intent to grind past the story content.



Thus it has its ups and downs, although most of these problems do not recur in the other games so it's nice knowing that they have genuinely improved overtime beyond just getting new features. A very positive experience in the end though despite its issues, especially considering how old the game is. Even just playing through the story, huge amounts of value given the price.

I picked this up for under £4.00 in a recent Steam sale and it shows Steam's ability to get gamers to games they'd never heard about.

    Disgaea from the reviews was obviously really big news on the consoles but I'd never heard about it.

    For what will be a moderately long review I can summarise thus - fun, colourful, with a definite Japanse sensibility, but with what amounts to a huge strategic complexity which for half of the game can be averted by having your main character beat the tush out of everything in sight.  There are flaws but they don't stop it being a good game.

    So - the game.  You are a demon prince just awoken from a two year slumber to find your father dead and the kingdom, ahem, gone to hell.  Your job is to beat the tar out of everyone in the way of reclaiming your throne (that's how the game starts anyway - I haven't finished it yet).  So the game breaks down into three - narrative cut scenes talking comic book style (so they flick between still images),  turn based battles on a grid, and healing and item sorting between battles.

   The story has it's tongue firmly implanted in the cheek - so there's a slight disconnect betweeen your murderous rampages and the narrative.  There's some suggestion that certainly major character just are beaten up rather than killed.

   The sensibility is Japanse manga.  So if your blood vessels burst at characters that look twelve dressed in bondage gear, or little girl dresses, or maids' outfits walk away.  There seems to be nothing racier than the costumes so far and so far nothing approaching sex or nudity in the game.

   The game follows the standard RPG mote -kill monsters, loot, get XP, level up, get better weapons and kit, kill more monsters etc etc.  However with up to ten characters in play and over a dozen classes the potential strategic complexity is huge.  You also can fight through a series of ten consecutive battles to improve your gear.  The game is played out on square grid maps.  The maps can have coloured squares which are influenced by coloured pyramids that give things like XP boosts, ability modifiers, ability blockers, hit point drain, and invulnerability.  It's a good idea to check out what the pyramids on each map are doing before you deploy.

    Game levels tend to split into four types.  The first is where your squad clearly outmatches the enemy and you can have fun picking which character makes the kill to pick up the XP.  The second is a tough battle where frequently your super tough main character will be only character left standing.  The third is a tough set up that you'll need to try a couple of times to gain a victory. The fourth is the sort of nightmare that sends you to the walkthroughs or back to item  world to grind out some extra levels.  I've just had my morale broken by a map at the start of Chapter 7 where the map is filled with mid 20s enemies (only my main demon is tougher) but there are also inaccessible x3 enemy modifiers.

    Things I wished I knew when I started (very minor spoilers but believe me you'll thank me)

    1)  The store has TWO sides.  So one side sells accessories the other side sells kit.  I went through 24 hours of play before I found where they sold weapons and armour.
    2)  Weapons ARE class specific but can be used by other classes at a penalty.  They should make this clear.  They don't.  Does this apply to other kit too ?  It's major because fighter can't use specials if they are wearing brawler gloves.  Check the character sheet for signifiers.
    3) The final battle of part 1 is a total killer - by far the toughest battle in the game so far.  You can redo battles to build XP and you can go on item boosts.  BEWARE.  The item boosts need you to win ten consecutive fights.  I wouldn't consider it until you have to do it in game.  I'd definitely replay the first three levels repeatedly to boost stats and then buy some extra characters to boost your party.  If you take out the red pyramids and your main character is still intact you should win.
   4) Go to the hospital and heal up and save after each battle.
   5) Keep using your special powers to level them up.
    6)  I used an X-Box for PC controller and had no control problems whatsoever.
     7) Healers are badly disadvantaged.  You get XP by killing things so my healer who has got the party through dozens of levels is falling further and further behind on his stats.  Healers wear dresses, have feminine features, and male voices.
     8) None of the weapons next to your spawn can be picked up.
     9)  Spoiler alert significant - but you'll be very grateful.  After the game first starts click behind your throne and on the skull on the shop counter. Click yes to flick both switches.  Then click on the wall near the Prinny (penguin) complaining about a draft.  This unlocks a secret room.  Read Etna's journal there each level and after you finish the game Etna mode will be unlocked.
    10) Spoiler alert major - but again you'll be grateful.  To get the "good" ending you need to win without killing any ally during battle.  This sounds like a no-brainer but on item world you can have clones and warp - also item world can be very uneven leaving character hard to see and possibly vulnerable to your area attack spells.  However if you mess up you can just replay the game - which means that 75% of the game is a walk in the park for your high level characters.

  The game is very repetitive but so is chess.  And chess doesn't allow you to use the "Big Bang" as a special attack.  Or have warrior penguins.  When this game next goes on sale it's definitely time for you to "Turn Japanese".

S.x.

41330097.review:
Disgaea is a cornerstone series of Strategy JRPGs, known for having long endgames chock full of Level 9999 enemies that drop Infinity+9 Swords and superbosses that redefine "one-hit kill". Thus, while effort is put toward the "main game", everyone knows the real strengths are after you've gotten your first story ending.

I don't have hundreds of hours with this game, but I am very familiar with the series, enough that I feel I can give a somewhat-accurate assessment of the first game.

That said...

[b]Gameplay[/b]-wise, this is the game that sets the standard for Disgaea. Despite small changes and additions, every single main Disgaea game after this one follows the same rules that this game outlines: up to 10 units on the same map at one time, physical attacks use ATK or HIT against DEF while magic uses INT against RES, evasion and accuracy are determined by HIT and SPD, and other factors need to be considered, such as positioning, Counter-attacks, and map Height.

Noted changes from later games that are necessary to note:
[list]
[*]All Monster characters have 100% Aptitudes in all fields, with the only exceptions being Galactic Demons (with 150% DEF/RES), so no specializing, but no mechanical weaknesses (in theory).
[*]Monster characters can only use Red weapons. Blue weapons don't exist.
[*]Related to the above point, INT-based Monster classes are pretty much screwed, since almost every unique Monster ability is based on ATK (with few exceptions).
[*]Fists use ATK only (like all other non-ranged weapons), rather than ATK/SPD mix, so stocking Ninjas with pure SPD makes them hard to hit, but they'll strike like a wet blanket. Guns use HIT, rather than HIT/SPD mix; they also have the same unlimited direction as Bows.
[*]If you're running a Healer at any point, realize that all Heal spells are based on INT, not RES. Yes, that means Skulls/Mages make for better Healers than the actual Healers.
[*]Monster classes are unlocked by killing each tier of the class, unlike later games, where tiers are unlocked via level. Also, Mana costs for Monster creation are obnoxiously high unless you've killed multiple units of said tiers (~30 on average).
[*]Thieves are both useless and useful. For regular battles, they have completely garbage stats and aptitudes. That being said, they can throw up to 6 spaces, steal stats (although [spoiler]Thursday[/spoiler] can too), and have a maximum steal chance of 99%, so you can get R40s a lot easier.
[*]Majin are basically OP in this game. Once you've got them, they're all you need, since 110% Aptitudes minimum and S rank weapon mastery speak for themselves.[/list]

[b]Graphically[/b], this game actually has much different lighting and color-design than later games. It gives it a bit of a darker feel, alongside the slightly-more warped character design, and I quite like it. Otherwise, sprite detail is fairly high-quality, as is map variety.

This port of the game runs pretty well, I've found. It remains [b]stable[/b], although that's not very hard considering it's presentation. Very few framedrops, and it's not too memory-intensive.

[b]Music[/b] is a nice high point; there's a lot of instantly-memorable melodies and catchy songs, plus [spoiler]Kurtis'[/spoiler] theme is just legendary.

Disgaea 1's [b]story[/b] is probably the most well-known of all the main games, although I think that has more to do with the fact that it had an anime adaptation. Still, the number of branching endings allows for quite a lot of varied approaches to your run, and the game even allows you to replay the main game over and over again, if you want new ways of playing through certain scenarios. Also, these games are well-known as JRPG parodies, and the writing is suitably funny and mocking of said tropes.

Quick note: [spoiler]If you want the good ending, try not to kill a single ally. That's sounds easy, but you'd be surprised how much damage you start dealing past 50, in addition to how easy it is to forget that friendly fire exists and that sprites are actually fairly small.[/spoiler]

This port to the PC also comes with [b]additional content[/b] that was only available in the various ports of this game, such as certain additional scenarios in the post-game. Basically, this is the full package if you're looking for added content. The artbook is also kind of nice, if you're into that.

Also: I've heard, from multiple reviews, that there are some problems regarding the game's ported controls and other related things. I've had no problems with controls, but I will say that mouse control is weirdly floaty as hell, hence I played using just keyboard with some re-binded keys. That's something to keep in mind, also, since some keys don't bind freely.

TL;DR: This port is a perfectly playable, fully complete package that, although kinda clunky mechanics-wise (in my opinion, as a dude who came into Disgaea via 4), is a perfect starting point for anyone wanting to get into the Disgaea universe.

[b]Scores for people who don't like reading:
Gameplay: 8/10[/b] It's a Strategy JRPG, with customizable characters, long-as-hell post-game, and a system that is simple and intuitive enough, with some minor flaws. It's a cornerstone of SRPGs for a reason.
[b]Sound/Music: 8/10[/b] Music fits the situation, there's nothing ear-grating, and everything is, at the very least, pleasant to listen to.
[b]Story: 7/10[/b] English or Japanese, some of the writing is generic, but hey, it's hilarious all the same.
[b]Difficulty: 6/10[/b] There is nothing that can't be solved with an assload of grinding. Being the first game, though, the grinding is pretty slow, so some things might remain difficult for a while. This is especially true as the story winds down, since enemies start scaling both level- and damage-wise at an exponential rate. It's called "Grinding: the Game" for a reason.
[b]Accessability: 7/10[/b] This game is very hit-or-miss on explaining some mechanics in certain ways (diagonal throwing, fusion, capturing, mastery), but everything is intuitive in some way.

[b]Average: 7.2/10[/b] Do yourself a favor and play this game. It's a solid strategy game, decently challenging, and has some hilarious writing.

Disgaea is a port of the very first Disgaea game that started this very succesful series of games. It's a niche tactical RPG that is mainly meant for people that like tactics RPGs with a lot of grinding.

[h1]Pro's[/h1]
[list]
[*]Essentially, everything is crazy in this game. The level cap for a character is 9999 (technically even more) and you can do damage that goes into tens- if not hundred thousands. 
[*]There is a huge amount of customization available through a wide range of humanoid classes, and on top of that you can even catch every monster that you encounter to have them fight along your side - pokémon-style. 
[*]The game is pretty old by now, so graphically it's not very pretty to look at. I do really like the style that was used to portray all the special moves and such though, it looks great.
[*]The music isn't amazing, but after grinding for a while you start to appreciate it.
[*]The story starts off slow and it's completely weird. For example, [spoiler]there is an entire chapter dedicated to preventing someone from spreading an embarrassing picture of the main character[/spoiler]. I really enjoyed it as it was a breeze of fresh air having a different storyline for once.
[*]There is a lot of endgame content available after the storyline.

[/list]
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]The game is really innovative in the sense that it introduces a lot of systems that you probably never heard of. For example, you can level up items by "entering" them, you can lift characters to make a huge tower of characters and some of your allies that you can "throw" will actually explode (and therefore die), essentially turning them into a grenade. 
[*]There is a lot of grinding involved. You don't see that anymore nowadays as there are often pay2win or otherwise easily accessible ways to skip grinding, but this one very much so has the typical grind in which you repeat a level over and over again to raise some numbers. I can imagine people aren't going to like this because of that
[*]The game is so [i]out there[/i] and totally insane sometimes, that I can imagine it scares people off.
[/list]

[h1]Extra info[/h1]
There are some things I like to know when it comes to tactical RPGs, which you might like to know before you start playing as well: 

[list]
[*]There is no permadeath
[*](This one's obvious) you can go back to grind finished maps
[*]In regards to losing characters along the storyline that you've spent a lot of time on only for them to dissapear from the game all of the sudden: [spoiler]you don't permanently lose any characters[/spoiler]
[*]If you follow the storyline you will be around level [spoiler]100 to 150[/spoiler] when you finish the main story.
[/list]

To me, this is one of the big staple games for tactical RPG lovers, next to greats such as Fire Emblem, Final Fantasy Tactics and maybe the more modern XCOM series. But you really require an open mind for some of it's weird systems. Don't pick this game up if it's your first tactics RPG, but definitely get it if you appreciate the genre.

I had played and mostly finish it on PS2 a butt-load of years ago, and well... Why not try it on PC with the huge sale it got. Is it good, is it bad? As I usually do I'm gonna start with the negative stuff, then move up from there.

First and foremost, the controls. Keyboard and mouse controls are suicide-inducing. It took me less than an hour to tell them to f#ck off and plug the XBOX 360 controller. Way better. I will also say that there's some sort of problem with the mouse controls, at it doesn't seem to respond to some of the clicks for some reason.

Second, parts of the gameplay. Now you gotta understand something, this was the first game of the series, and after having beaten 2, 3 and 4 it shows. Some special attacks are redundant, healers are stupidly useless and will hardly level up (as you need to kill to get experience and healers suck at hurting), monster-type characters are kinda useless compared to humanoids, that kinda stuff. The biggest issue is that the Dark Assembly, the game's government, is just... Harsh. From the start of the game it'll take a few tries to get anything passed on it. The game is build so you just kill the ones that don't agree with you or bribe them, however early on it's nearly impossible to be successful at either. Thankfully most (if not all) of these problems got fixed in future games.

Also, the story has a few stale parts. Scenes that go for too long, mainly. It's not until the mid-game when the story starts to get more interesting. I will also say, the tutorial at the start of the game is forced. Shouldn't you be able to skip it? Sure you can skip it at New Game+, but I mean on your first playthrough. Sure it has some humor on it, but if you already know how to play it then it's just you hitting the A button over and over for a few minutes.

Lastly, the last episodes have a weird raise on enemy levels compared with the others, on which they raised them slowly so your characters could keep up. However in the last chapter enemies start around 50 or so and to the final battle you're suddenly batting against a 90 lvl final boss with a bunch of similar leveled enemies with him. Sure, the game expects you to grind at some moment, after all that's what the franchise was build on, the post-game cool stuff... But it's a raise of levels a bit too sudden and rushed.

That being said, the game is quite fun to play and offers a f#ck-truck of content for a really fair asking price on a sale.

The story, ignoring those scenes that last longer than they should, it's entertaining. Not too many characters, and most of them are well developed (Sadly other characters such as [spoiler]bosses you recluited or Kartus at the end[/spoiler] don't get too much of it). And the humor is actually alright, with the game ocasionally becoming self-aware and laughing it up along with yourself.

The game also has plenty of references and shout-outs that are fun when you actually notice them. Now sure, sequels become an INSANE OVERDOSE of references, but in this game is more tame.

The post-game stuff is is also great. Not only the game has plenty of endings and an extra story that's not really canon but it's fun to play, but the game also has plenty of stages and secret bosses after you're done with the main game. Though expect the grind, as the main story will end with you around level 80 or so and some of the secret bosses are around 1000. There's plenty of spots where grinding can become a breeze (specially during the story, incase you're having issues with a boss in particular), so don't worry too much.

I also find like this game had some of the best characters, no wonder most of them appear in later games over and over. Laharl, Flonne, Etna, Mid-boss, they have better character development than the characters on the third game (which might I add, the third game had a stupidly short story). Sure there's not many choices when it comes to making your own characters as in the future games, but the story ones the game has are quite interesting and fun to keep up with.

Do I recommend this game? Yeah! If you don't mind turn-based strategy rpg games, then jump right in. But remember this: Disgaea 2 is better, as the devs learned from the first game and fixed the problems the game had. This game is good, you'll probably enjoy it, but I suggest you at some moment move to the sequel. It's better in almost every way.

TL;DR Edition: It's a fun PS2 game which has a f#ckload of content, though the keyboard and mouse controls feel as horrible as you would expect. The sequel might be better, but you're still getting your money back on a really long game with plenty of content (and out-of-context sexual comments made by Laharl).

37432690.review:
First off, though it had a rough release with a lot of nasty glitches, these have been since corrected. The voice acting is still cringe-worthy, but the writing is epic. So with the only real two issues out of the way, let's get into why Disgaea is amazing.

First off, Disgaea understands its audience intimately. People who played FFT and similar games loved the in-depth story arcs, the incredible customization, the complex tactical combat and having so much extra stuff to do that playthroughs which take over one hundred hours still allow for immense replay value anyway. Disgaea takes all of these concepts and expands upon them to absurd levels.

So, story-wise, the story itself is absurd, yet amazing. The specific dialogue is exceptionally self-aware and knows just how silly it is - for example, at one point the "protagonists" (honestly, it's more like you're playing the antagonists), are attacked by obvious power ranger wannabes... and then during the ranger's attempted stereotypical transformation sequence, they just get shot. With a gun. And then throw a fit because you're not allowed to do that during a heroic transformation sequence. The end-of-chapter previews are... useless for knowing what will happen in the next chapter as they usually have little to no relation whatsoever, yet are amusing as hell, so yay anyway.

The gameplay's amazing, with puzzles to solve in-combat, particularly within the item world sections. Being able to throw characters and objects allows for some surprisingly complex tasks and unique level design, and your choice of abilities and characters allows for a lot of customization in how you play.

Disgaea's greatest strength, though, is its replay factor. It's a grindy game. That's the point. If you like these types of games, you generally also enjoy maxing out characters in a wide variety of tasks and classes, teaching them to be amazing at everything they do. The level cap is 9999, and you can even specialize weapons and armour, or even health potions if you want, by going into the item itself and battling your way through such to increase the stats or to defeat special hidden characters in the items which give bonuses and can be transferred to other items, allowing for rather ridiculous levels of customization and augmentation. It's a game that's fun to play, and it goes out of its way to give you excuses to drag the game on longer, such as a wealth of hidden bosses and extra story arcs to be unlocked well after the base game is beaten. Given how surprisingly long the base game is, and that much extra content being available, it's easy to spend literally hundreds of hours playing Disgaea.

Basically the story is ridiculous and epic, the characters are interesting and well-defined in personality, the gameplay's great and it goes out of its way to make sure you have every excuse to keep playing. It's basically the perfect tactical RPG custom tailored to be exactly what that player base enjoys.

That you get to play as the villains is really just a bonus. =P
